classes.name: Block
classes.description: A block in a world. It has a location and a type, and can also have a direction (mostly a facing), an inventory, or other special properties.

classes.name: Block Data
classes.description: Block data is the detailed information about a block, referred to in Minecraft as BlockStates, allowing for the manipulation of different aspects of the block, including shape, waterlogging, direction the block is facing, and so much more. Information regarding each block's optional data can be found on Minecraft's Wiki. Find the block you're looking for and scroll down to 'Block States'. Different states must be separated by a semicolon (see examples). The 'minecraft:' namespace is optional, as well as are underscores.
classes.examples:
set block at player to campfire[lit=false]
set target block of player to oak stairs[facing=north;waterlogged=true]
set block at player to grass_block[snowy=true]
set loop-block to minecraft:chest[facing=north]
set block above player to oak_log[axis=y]
set target block of player to minecraft:oak_leaves[distance=2;persistent=false]

classes.name: Boolean
classes.description: A boolean is a value that is either true or false. Other accepted names are 'on' and 'yes' for true, and 'off' and 'no' for false.

classes.name: Cat Type
patterns: red, all black, british shorthair, ragdoll, white, jellie, siamese, black, tabby, calico, persian
classes.description: Represents the race/type of a cat entity.

classes.name: Chunk
classes.description: A chunk is a cuboid of 16×16×128 (x×z×y) blocks. Chunks are spread on a fixed rectangular grid in their world.

classes.name: Click Type

classes.name: Color

classes.description: Wool, dye and chat colors.
classes.examples: color of the sheep is red or black\nset the color of the block to green\nmessage "You're holding a &amp;amp;amp;amp;lt;%color of tool%&amp;amp;amp;amp;gt;%color of tool%&amp;amp;amp;amp;lt;reset&amp;amp;amp;amp;gt; wool block"

classes.name: Command Sender
patterns: use the console for the console
classes.description: A player or the console.
classes.examples:
command /push [&amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;lt;player&amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;gt;]:
    trigger:
        if arg-1 is not set:
            if command sender is console:
                send "You can't push yourself as a console :" to sender
                stop
            push sender upwards with force 2
            send "Yay!"
        else:
            push arg-1 upwards with force 2
            send "Yay!" to sender and arg-1

classes.name: Damage Cause
patterns: sweep attack, thorns, the void, magma, a lightning, drowning, dragonfire, an attack, drown, an entity attack, melt, freeze, falling block, contact, fire, an entity explosion, lightning, a fall, entity explosion, void, a lightning strike, suffocation, suicide, wither effect, a plugin, lightning strike, entity attack, a potion, a wither, sweeping, melting, a falling block, unknown, starvation, lava, fall, hot floor, attack, a block explosion, dryout, burn, hitting wall while flying, potion, world border, flying into a wall, cramming, poison, sonic boom, suffocate, custom, kill, killed, a fire, burning, a projectile, plugin, wither potion effect, block explosion, projectile, wither, dragon's breath
classes.description: The cause/type of a damage event, e.g. lava, fall, fire, drowning, explosion, poison, etc.\nPlease note that support for this type is very rudimentary, e.g. lava, fire and burning, as well as projectile and attack are considered different types.

classes.name: Date
classes.description: A date is a certain point in the real world's time which can be obtained with now expression, unix date expression and date function.\nSee time and timespan for the other time types of Skript.
classes.examples: set {_yesterday} to now\nsubtract a day from {_yesterday}\n# now {_yesterday} represents the date 24 hours before now

classes.name: Difficulty
classes.description: The difficulty of a world.

classes.name: Direction
classes.description: A direction, e.g. north, east, behind, 5 south east, 1.3 meters to the right, etc.\nLocations and some blocks also have a direction, but without a length.\nPlease note that directions have changed extensively in the betas and might not work perfectly. They can also not be used as command arguments.
classes.examples: set the block below the victim to a chest\nloop blocks from the block infront of the player to the block 10 below the player:\n    set the block behind the loop-block to water

classes.name: Enchantment
patterns: Efficiency, Looting, Soul Speed, Silk Touch, Quick Charge, Flame, Fortune, Aqua Affinity, Multishot, Channeling, Loyalty, Curse of Binding, Punch, Projectile Protection, Power, Sharpness, Frost Walker, Fire Protection, Impaling, Luck of The Sea, Riptide, Protection, Mending, Respiration, Piercing, Unbreaking, Swift Sneak, Feather Falling, Lure, Smite, Fire Aspect, Knockback, Depth Strider, Sweeping Edge, Infinity, Curse of Vanishing, Blast Protection, Bane of Arthropods, Thorns

classes.name: Enchantment Offer
classes.description: The enchantmentoffer in an enchant prepare event.
classes.examples: on enchant prepare:\n    set enchant offer 1 to sharpness 1\n    set the cost of enchant offer 1 to 10 levels

classes.name: Enchantment Type
classes.description: An enchantment with an optional level, e.g. 'sharpness 2' or 'fortune'.
classes.examples: enchant the player's tool with sharpness 5\nhelmet is enchanted with waterbreathing

classes.name: Entity
patterns: player, op, wolf, tamed ocelot, powered creeper, zombie, unsaddled pig, fireball, arrow, dropped item, item frame, etc.
classes.description: An entity is something in a world that's not a block, e.g. a player, a skeleton, or a zombie, but also projectiles like arrows, fireballs or thrown potions, or special entities like dropped items, falling blocks or paintings.
classes.examples:
entity is a zombie or creeper
player is an op
projectile is an arrow
shoot a fireball from the player

classes.name: Entity Type
classes.description: The type of an entity, e.g. player, wolf, powered creeper, etc.
classes.examples: victim is a cow\nspawn a creeper

classes.name: Entity Type with Amount
classes.description: An entity type with an amount, e.g. '2 zombies'. I might remove this type in the future and make a more general 'type' type, i.e. a type that has a number and a type.

classes.name: Experience
classes.description: Experience points. Please note that Bukkit only allows to give XP, but not remove XP from players. You can however change a player's level and level progress freely.

classes.name: Firework Effect
classes.description: A configuration of effects that defines the firework when exploded\nwhich can be used in the launch firework effect.\nSee the firework effect expression for detailed patterns.
classes.examples: launch flickering trailing burst firework colored blue and green at player\nlaunch trailing flickering star colored purple, yellow, blue, green and red fading to pink at target entity\nlaunch ball large colored red, purple and white fading to light green and black at player's location with duration 1

classes.name: Firework Type
patterns: small, ball, star shaped, large, star, creeper face, small ball, large ball, burst, ball large, creeper
classes.description: The type of a fireworkeffect.

classes.name: Game Mode
classes.description: The game modes survival, creative, adventure and spectator.
classes.examples: player's gamemode is survival\nset the player argument's game mode to creative

classes.description: Represents a Panda's main or hidden gene. See genetics for more info.

classes.name: Heal Reason
patterns: an ender crystal, magic, a magic regeneration, magic regeneration, fed, sated, a magic regen, regen potion, a wither spawn, peaceful, unknown, a regeneration potion, consuming, a wither effect, peaceful regeneration, wither summoning, healing potion, wither potion, an end crystal, satiated, regeneration potion, potion, satisfied, ingesting, withered, custom, a wither spawning, end crystal, eating, wither spawning, a wither summoning, wither effect, a plugin, a regen potion, plugin, withering, a potion, wither spawn, a healing potion, ender crystal, magic regen, wither, peaceful regen

classes.name: Inventory
classes.description: An inventory of a player or block. Inventories have many effects and conditions regarding the items contained.\nAn inventory has a fixed amount of slots which represent a specific place in the inventory, e.g. the helmet slot for players (Please note that slot support is still very limited but will be improved eventually).

classes.name: Inventory Action
patterns: drop stack from slot, swap items with hotbar, swap cursor stack, pickup single item, pickup some, drop all from cursor, move to other inventory, drop cursor stack, pickup all, swap with hotbar, nothing, drop all from slot, swap cursor, drop cursor, pickup all items, drop slot item, place all, drop cursor item, drop slot stack, drop single item from slot, swap with cursor, place some, pickup one item, drop single item from cursor, collect items to cursor, unknown, clone stack, drop stack from cursor, drop one item from slot, drop one item from cursor, unsupported, do nothing, drop one from cursor, pickup half, drop items from slot, swap stack with cursor, place all items, collect to cursor, pickup some items, drop slot, drop items from cursor, hotbar move and readd, shift move, custom, pickup single, place one item, hotbar swap items, drop one from slot, place some items, place one, pickup half stack, instant move, hotbar swap
classes.description: What player just did in inventory event. Note that when in creative game mode, most actions do not work correctly.

classes.name: Inventory Close Reasons
patterns: disconnect, death, teleport, cannot use, new opened, unknown, can't use, unloaded, disconnected, plugin, can not use, open new, player
classes.description: The inventory close reason in an inventory close event.

classes.name: Inventory Slot
classes.description: Represents a single slot of an inventory. Notable slots are the armour slots and furnace slots. \nThe most important property that distinguishes a slot from an item is its ability to be changed, e.g. it can be set, deleted, enchanted, etc. (Some item expressions can be changed as well, e.g. items stored in variables. For that matter: slots are never saved to variables, only the items they represent at the time when the variable is set).\nPlease note that tool can be regarded a slot, but it can actually change it's position, i.e. doesn't represent always the same slot.
classes.examples:
set tool of player to dirt
delete helmet of the victim
set the color of the player's tool to green
enchant the player's chestplate with projectile protection 5

classes.name: Inventory Type
patterns: barrel inventory, a loom inventory, a blast furnace inventory, workbench inventory, ender chest inventory, loom inventory, a workbench inventory, hopper inventory, a merchant inventory, a hopper inventory, chiseled bookshelf, an ender chest inventory, new smithing table, bookshelf, a jukebox, beacon inventory, shulker box inventory, a barrel inventory, a shulker box inventory, lectern inventory, chest inventory, a villager inventory, a smoker inventory, a brewing stand inventory, a smithing inventory, grindstone inventory, a crafting table inventory, a player inventory, furnace inventory, a creative inventory, blast furnace inventory, upgrade gear, a composter inventory, an enchanting table inventory, jukebox, a dropper inventory, a cartography table inventory, a upgrade gear, smoker inventory, composter inventory, a chest inventory, upgrade gear table, a upgrade gear table, dispenser inventory, player inventory, stonecutter inventory, a stonecutter inventory, a lectern inventory, merchant inventory, cartography table inventory, a chiseled bookshelf, a new smithing table, a furnace inventory, anvil inventory, a dispenser inventory, a grindstone inventory, smithing inventory, dropper inventory, brewing stand inventory, villager inventory, enchanting table inventory, a beacon inventory, a bookshelf, creative inventory, crafting table inventory, an anvil inventory
classes.description: Minecraft has several different inventory types with their own use cases.

classes.name: Item
patterns: [<number> [of]] <alias> [of <enchantment> <level>], Where <alias> must be an alias that represents exactly one item (i.e cannot be a general alias like 'sword' or 'plant')
classes.description: An item, e.g. a stack of torches, a furnace, or a wooden sword of sharpness 2. Unlike item type an item can only represent exactly one item (e.g. an upside-down cobblestone stair facing west), while an item type can represent a whole range of items (e.g. any cobble stone stairs regardless of direction).\nYou don't usually need this type except when you want to make a command that only accepts an exact item.\nPlease note that currently 'material' is exactly the same as 'item', i.e. can have an amount & enchantments.
classes.examples: set {_item} to type of the targeted block\n{_item} is a torch

classes.name: Item Type
classes.description: An item type is an alias, e.g. 'a pickaxe', 'all plants', etc., and can result in different items when added to an inventory, and unlike items they are well suited for checking whether an inventory contains a certain item or whether a certain item is of a certain type.\nAn item type can also have one or more enchantments with or without a specific level defined, and can optionally start with 'all' or 'every' to make this item type represent all types that the alias represents, including data ranges.
classes.examples:
give 4 torches to the player
add all slabs to the inventory of the block
player's tool is a diamond sword of sharpness
remove a pickaxes of fortune 4 from {stored items::*}
set {_item} to 10 of every upside-down stair
block is dirt or farmland

classes.name: Living Entity
patterns: see entity, but ignore inanimate objects
classes.description: A living entity, i.e. a mob or player, not inanimate entities like projectiles or dropped items.
classes.examples: spawn 5 powered creepers\nshoot a zombie from the creeper

classes.name: Location
classes.description: A location in a world. Locations are world-specific and even store a direction, e.g. if you save a location and later teleport to it you will face the exact same direction you did when you saved the location.

classes.name: Metadata Holder
classes.description: Something that can hold metadata (e.g. an entity or block)
classes.examples: set metadata value "super cool" of player to true

classes.name: Money
patterns: <number> $ or $ <number>, where '$' is your server's currency, e.g. '10 rupees' or '£5.00'
classes.description: A certain amount of money. Please note that this differs from numbers as it includes a currency symbol or name, but usually the two are interchangeable, e.g. you can both add 100$ to the player's balance and add 100 to the player's balance.
classes.examples:
add 10£ to the player's account
remove Fr. 9.95 from the player's money
set the victim's money to 0
increase the attacker's balance by the level of the victim * 100

classes.name: Moon Phase
patterns: last quarter, waning crescent, waxing gibbous, full moon, waning gibbous, waxing crescent, new moon, first quarter
classes.description: Represents the phase of a moon.

classes.name: Number
patterns: [-]###[.###] (any amount of digits; very large numbers will be truncated though)
classes.description: A number, e.g. 2.5, 3, or -9812454.\nPlease note that many expressions only need integers, i.e. will discard any fractional parts of any numbers without producing an error.
classes.examples: set the player's health to 5.5\nset {_temp} to 2*{_temp} - 2.5

classes.name: Object
classes.description: The supertype of all types, meaning that if %object% is used in e.g. a condition it will accept all kinds of expressions.

classes.name: Offline Player
classes.description: A player that is possibly offline. See player for more information. Please note that while all effects and conditions that require a player can be used with an offline player as well, they will not work if the player is not actually online.

classes.name: Player
classes.description: A player. Depending on whether a player is online or offline several actions can be performed with them, though you won't get any errors when using effects that only work if the player is online (e.g. changing their inventory) on an offline player.\nYou have two possibilities to use players as command arguments: <player> and <offline player>. The first requires that the player is online and also accepts only part of the name, while the latter doesn't require that the player is online, but the player's name has to be entered exactly.

classes.name: Potion Effect
classes.description: A potion effect, including the potion effect type, tier and duration.

classes.name: Potion Effect Type
patterns: null, speed, slowness, haste, mining fatigue, strength, instant health, instant damage, jump boost, nausea, regeneration, resistance, fire resistance, water breathing, invisibility, blindness, night vision, hunger, weakness, poison, wither, health boost, absorption, saturation, glowing, levitation, luck, bad luck, slow falling, conduit power, dolphins grace, bad omen, hero of the village, darkness
classes.description: A potion effect type, e.g. 'strength' or 'swiftness'.
classes.examples: apply swiftness 5 to the player\napply potion of speed 2 to the player for 60 seconds\nremove invisibility from the victim

classes.name: Projectile
patterns: arrow, fireball, snowball, thrown potion, etc.
classes.description: A projectile, e.g. an arrow, snowball or thrown potion.
classes.examples: projectile is a snowball\nshoot an arrow at speed 5 from the player

classes.name: Quit Reason
patterns: disconnected, erroneous state, kicked, quit, timed out, erroneous
classes.description: Represents a quit reason from a player quit server event.

classes.name: Region
classes.description: A region of a regions plugin. Skript currently supports WorldGuard, Factions, GriefPrevention and PreciousStones.\nPlease note that some regions plugins do not have named regions, some use numerical ids to identify regions, and some may have regions with the same name in different worlds, thus using regions like "region name" in scripts may or may not work.

classes.name: Resource Pack State
patterns: refused, rejected, accepted, failed, failed to download, successfully loaded, accept, fail, successfully load, refuse, declined, successfully install, success, reject, decline, successfully installed, download fail
classes.description: The state in a resource pack request response event.

classes.name: Server Icon
classes.description: A server icon that was loaded using the load server icon effect.

classes.name: Sound Category
patterns: hostile creatures category, speech category, records category, friendly creature category, noteblock category, hostile creature category, note block category, voice category, ambient category, noteblocks category, note blocks category, weather category, block category, friendly mob category, jukebox category, hostile mob category, master category, master volume category, hostile category, record category, blocks category, environment category, jukeboxes category, player category, players category, hostile mobs category, friendly mobs category, music category, friendly creatures category, neutral category
classes.description: The category of a sound, they are used for sound options of Minecraft. See the play sound and stop sound effects.

classes.name: Spawn Reason
patterns: dispense egg, egg, village defense, ocelot baby, silverfish trap, village invading, trap, dispensing egg, shoulder, drowned, metamorphosis, lightning, silverfish reveal, spell, built iron golem, natural, village invasion, frozen, mount, build wither, built wither, iron golem defense, ender pearl, creature spawner, reinforcements, build snowman, build iron golem, breeding, raid, infection, customized, spawn egg, jockey, beehive, default, golem defense, patrol, slime split, infected, sheared, mob spawner, nether portal, shear, perching, custom, built snowman, chunk generation, breed, command, duplication, explosion, spawner, cured, customised, piglin zombification
classes.description: The spawn reason in a spawn event.

classes.name: Teleport Cause
patterns: bed exit, nether portal, ender gateway, exiting bed, chorus fruit, ender portal, command, unknown, plugin, dismounted, ender pearl, spectator, spectate, end gateway, chorus, exit bed, gateway, dismount, end portal
classes.description: The teleport cause in a teleport event.

classes.name: Text
classes.description: Text is simply text, i.e. a sequence of characters, which can optionally contain expressions which will be replaced with a meaningful representation (e.g. %player% will be replaced with the player's name).\nBecause scripts are also text, you have to put text into double quotes to tell Skript which part of the line is an effect/expression and which part is the text.\nPlease read the article on Texts and Variable Names to learn more.
classes.examples: broadcast "Hello World!"\nmessage "Hello %player%"\nmessage "The id of ""%type of tool%"" is %id of tool%."

classes.name: Time
classes.description: A time is a point in a minecraft day's time (i.e. ranges from 0:00 to 23:59), which can vary per world.\nSee date and timespan for the other time types of Skript.

classes.name: Timeperiod
classes.description: A period of time between two times. Mostly useful since you can use this to test for whether it's day, night, dusk or dawn in a specific world.\nThis type might be removed in the future as you can use 'time of world is between x and y' as a replacement.

classes.name: Timespan
classes.description: A timespan is a difference of two different dates or times, e.g '10 minutes'. Timespans are always displayed as real life time, but can be defined as minecraft time, e.g. '5 minecraft days and 12 hours'.\nNOTE: Months always have the value of 30 days, and years of 365 days.\nSee date and time for the other time types of Skript.
classes.examples:
every 5 minecraft days:
    wait a minecraft second and 5 ticks
every 10 mc days and 12 hours:
    halt for 12.7 irl minutes, 12 hours and 120.5 seconds

classes.name: Tree Type
patterns: [any] <general tree/mushroom type>, e.g. tree/any jungle tree/etc.
<specific tree/mushroom species>, e.g. red mushroom/small jungle tree/big regular tree/etc.
classes.description: A tree type represents a tree species or a huge mushroom species. These can be generated in a world with the generate tree effect.
classes.examples: grow any regular tree at the block\ngrow a huge red mushroom above the block

classes.name: Type
patterns: See the type name patterns of all types - including this one
classes.description: Represents a type, e.g. number, object, item type, location, block, world, entity type, etc.\nThis is mostly used for expressions like 'event-<type>', '<type>-argument', 'loop-<type>', etc., e.g. event-world, number-argument and loop-player.
classes.examples:
{variable} is a number # check whether the variable contains a number, e.g. -1 or 5.5
{variable} is a type # check whether the variable contains a type, e.g. number or player
{variable} is an object # will always succeed if the variable is set as everything is an object, even types.
disable PvP in the event-world
kill the loop-entity

classes.name: Vector
classes.description: Vector is a collection of numbers. In Minecraft, 3D vectors are used to express velocities of entities.

classes.name: Visual Effect

classes.name: World
classes.description: One of the server's worlds. Worlds can be put into scripts by surrounding their name with double quotes, e.g. "world_nether", but this might not work reliably as text uses the same syntax.

classes.name: World Environment
patterns: normal, nether, the end, the overworld, custom, the nether, end, overworld
classes.description: Represents the environment of a world.

conditions.name: Alphanumeric
conditions.description: Checks if the given string is alphanumeric.
conditions.examples: if the argument is not alphanumeric:\n    send "Invalid name!"

conditions.name: Can Build
conditions.description: Tests whether a player is allowed to build at a certain location. This condition requires a supported regions plugin to be installed.
conditions.examples:
command /setblock &lt;material&gt;:
    description: set the block at your crosshair to a different type
    trigger:
        player cannot build at the targeted block:
            message "You do not have permission to change blocks there!"
            stop
        set the targeted block to argument

conditions.name: Can Fly
conditions.description: Whether a player is allowed to fly.
conditions.examples: player can fly

conditions.name: Can Hold
patterns: %inventories% (can(no|')t hold|(ha(s|ve) not|ha(s|ve)n't|do[es]n't have) [enough] space (for|to hold)) %item types%
conditions.description: Tests whether a player or a chest can hold the given item.
conditions.examples: block can hold 200 cobblestone\nplayer has enough space for 64 feathers

conditions.name: Can Pick Up Items
patterns: %living entities% can pick([ ]up items| items up)
%living entities% (can't|cannot|can not) pick([ ]up items| items up)
conditions.description: Whether living entities are able to pick up items off the ground or not.

conditions.name: Can See
conditions.description: Checks whether the given players can see another players.
conditions.examples: if the player can't see the player-argument:\n    message "&lt;light red&gt;The player %player-argument% is not online!"

conditions.name: Chance
conditions.description:
A condition that randomly succeeds or fails.
Valid values are between 0% and 100%, or if the percent sign is omitted between 0 and 1.
conditions.examples:
chance of 50%:
    drop a diamond
chance of {chance}% # {chance} between 0 and 100
chance of {chance} # {chance} between 0 and 1

conditions.name: Comparison
patterns: [(neither)] %objects% ((is|are)[(n't| not| neither)] (greater|more|higher|bigger|larger|above) [than] or (equal to|the same as)|>=) %objects%
[(neither)] %objects% ((is|are)[(n't| not| neither)] (less|smaller|lower|below) [than] or (equal to|the same as)|<=) %objects%
[(neither)] %objects% (is not|are not|isn't|aren't) between %objects% and %objects%
[(neither)] %objects% (was|were)[(n't| not| neither)] (greater|more|higher|bigger|larger|above) [than] or (equal to|the same as) %objects%
[(neither)] %objects% (was|were)[(n't| not| neither)] (less|smaller|lower|below) [than] or (equal to|the same as) %objects%
[(neither)] %objects% (was not|were not|wasn't|weren't) between %objects% and %objects%
[(neither)] %objects% (will be|(will (not|neither) be|won't be)) ((greater|more|higher|bigger|larger) than|above) %objects%
[(neither)] %objects% (will be|(will (not|neither) be|won't be)) (greater|more|higher|bigger|larger|above) [than] or (equal to|the same as) %objects%
[(neither)] %objects% (will be|(will (not|neither) be|won't be)) ((less|smaller|lower) than|below) %objects%
[(neither)] %objects% (will be|(will (not|neither) be|won't be)) (less|smaller|lower|below) [than] or (equal to|the same as) %objects%
[(neither)] %objects% ((will (not|neither) be|won't be)|(isn't|aren't|is not|are not) (turning|changing) [in]to) [equal to] %objects%
[(neither)] %objects% (will be [(equal to|the same as)]|(is|are) (turning|changing) [in]to) %objects%
[(neither)] %objects% will be between %objects% and %objects%
[(neither)] %objects% (will not be|won't be) between %objects% and %objects%
conditions.description: A very general condition, it simply compares two values. Usually you can only compare for equality (e.g. block is/isn't of <type>), but some values can also be compared using greater than/less than. In that case you can also test for whether an object is between two others. Note: This is the only element where not all patterns are shown. It has actually another two sets of similar patters, but with (was|were) or will be instead of (is|are) respectively, which check different time states of the first expression.
conditions.examples: the clicked block is a stone slab or a double stone slab\ntime in the player's world is greater than 8:00\nthe creature is not an enderman or an ender dragon

conditions.name: Contains
patterns: %inventories% (doesn't|does not|do not|don't) have %item types% [in [(the[ir]|his|her|its)] inventory]
%inventories/texts/objects% contain[s] %item types/texts/objects%
%inventories/texts/objects% (doesn't|does not|do not|don't) contain %item types/texts/objects%
conditions.description: Checks whether an inventory contains an item, a text contains another piece of text, or a list (e.g. {list variable::*} or 'drops') contains another object.
conditions.examples: block contains 20 cobblestone\nplayer has 4 flint and 2 iron ingots\n{list::*} contains 5

conditions.name: Damage Cause
conditions.description: Tests what kind of damage caused a damage event. Refer to the Damage Cause type for a list of all possible causes.
conditions.examples:
# make players use their potions of fire resistance whenever they take any kind of fire damage
on damage:
    damage was caused by lava, fire or burning
    victim is a player
    victim has a potion of fire resistance
    cancel event
    apply fire resistance to the victim for 30 seconds
    remove 1 potion of fire resistance from the victim
# prevent mobs from dropping items under certain circumstances
on death:
    entity is not a player
    damage wasn't caused by a block explosion, an attack, a projectile, a potion, fire, burning, thorns or poison
    clear drops

conditions.name: Do Respawn Anchors Work
patterns: respawn anchors [do[(n't| not)]] work in %worlds%
conditions.description: Checks whether or not respawn anchors work in a world.
conditions.examples: respawn anchors work in world "world_nether"

conditions.name: Egg Will Hatch
conditions.description: Whether the egg will hatch in a Player Egg Throw event.
conditions.examples: on player egg throw:\n    if an entity won't hatch:\n        send "Better luck next time!" to the player

conditions.name: Entity is Wet
conditions.description: Checks whether an entity is wet or not (in water, rain or a bubble column).
conditions.examples: if player is wet:

conditions.name: Entity is in Liquid
conditions.description: Checks whether an entity is in rain, lava, water or a bubble column.

conditions.name: Event Cancelled
conditions.description: Checks whether or not the event is cancelled.
conditions.examples: on click:\n    if event is cancelled:\n        broadcast "no clicks allowed!"

conditions.name: Exists/Is Set
conditions.description: Checks whether a given expression or variable is set.
conditions.examples:
{teams::%player's uuid%::preferred-team} is not set
on damage:
    projectile exists
    broadcast "%attacker% used a %projectile% to attack %victim%!"

conditions.name: Has AI
patterns: %living entities% (doesn't|does not|do not|don't) have (ai|artificial intelligence)
conditions.description: Checks whether an entity has AI.
conditions.examples: target entity has ai

conditions.name: Has Client Weather
conditions.description: Checks whether the given players have a custom client weather
conditions.examples: if the player has custom weather:\n    message "Your custom weather is %player's weather%"

conditions.name: Has Custom Model Data
patterns: %item types% (doesn't|does not|do not|don't) have [custom] model data
conditions.description: Check if an item has a custom model data tag
conditions.examples: player's tool has custom model data

conditions.name: Has Item Cooldown
patterns: %players% (doesn't|does not|do not|don't) have [([an] item|a)] cooldown (on|for) %item types%
%players% (doesn't|does not|do not|don't) have %item types% on [(item|a)] cooldown
conditions.description: Check whether a cooldown is active on the specified material for a specific player.
conditions.examples: if player has player's tool on cooldown:\n    send "You can't use this item right now. Wait %item cooldown of player's tool for player%"

conditions.name: Has Line of Sight
patterns: %living entities% (has|have) [a] [direct] line of sight to %entities/locations%
%living entities% does(n't| not) have [a] [direct] line of sight to %entities/locations%
%living entities% (has|have) no [direct] line of sight to %entities/locations%
conditions.description: Checks whether living entities have an unobstructed line of sight to other entities or locations.
conditions.examples: player has direct line of sight to location 5 blocks to the right of player\nvictim has line of sight to attacker\nplayer has no line of sight to location 100 blocks in front of player

conditions.name: Has Metadata
patterns: %metadata holders% (doesn't|does not|do not|don't) have metadata [(value|tag)[s]] %texts%
conditions.description: Checks whether a metadata holder has a metadata tag.
conditions.examples: if player has metadata value "healer":

conditions.name: Has Permission
conditions.description: Test whether a player has a certain permission.
conditions.examples: player has permission "skript.tree"\nvictim has the permission "admin":\n    send "You're attacking an admin!" to attacker

conditions.name: Has Played Before
patterns: %offline players% (has not|hasn't|have not|haven't|did not|didn't) [(already|yet)] play[ed] [on (this|the) server] (before|already|yet)
conditions.description: Checks whether a player has played on this server before. You can also use on first join if you want to make triggers for new players.
conditions.examples: player has played on this server before\nplayer hasn't played before

conditions.name: Has Potion
patterns: %living entities% (doesn't|does not|do not|don't) have potion[s] [effect[s]] %potions%
conditions.description: Checks whether the given living entities have specific potion effects.

conditions.name: Has Resource Pack
patterns: %players% (doesn't|does not|do not|don't) have [a] resource pack [(loaded|installed)]
conditions.description: Checks whether the given players have a server resource pack loaded. Please note that this can't detect player's own resource pack, only the resource pack that sent by the server.
conditions.examples: if the player has a resource pack loaded:

conditions.name: Has Scoreboard Tag
patterns: %entities% (doesn't|does not|do not|don't) have [the] score[ ]board tag[s] %texts%
conditions.description: Checks whether the given entities has the given scoreboard tags.
conditions.examples: if the targeted armor stand has the scoreboard tag "test tag":

conditions.name: Ignition Process
patterns: [creeper[s]] %living entities% ((is|are)|(isn't|is not|aren't|are not)) going to explode
[creeper[s]] %living entities% ((is|are)|(isn't|is not|aren't|are not)) in the (ignition|explosion) process
creeper[s] %living entities% ((is|are)|(isn't|is not|aren't|are not)) ignited
conditions.description: Checks if a creeper is going to explode.
conditions.examples: if the last spawned creeper is going to explode:\n    loop all players in radius 3 of the last spawned creeper\n        send "RUN!!!" to the loop-player

conditions.name: Is Alive
conditions.description: Checks whether an entity is alive. Works for non-living entities too.

conditions.name: Is Banned
conditions.description: Checks whether a player or IP is banned.
conditions.examples: player is banned\nvictim is not IP-banned\n"127.0.0.1" is banned

conditions.name: Is Bed/Anchor Spawn
conditions.description: Checks what the respawn location of a player in the respawn event is.
conditions.examples: on respawn:\n    the respawn location is a bed\n    broadcast "%player% is respawning in their bed! So cozy!"

conditions.name: Is Block
conditions.description: Checks whether an item is a block.
conditions.examples: player's held item is a block\n{list::*} are blocks

conditions.name: Is Block Redstone Powered
conditions.description: Checks if a block is indirectly or directly powered by redstone

conditions.name: Is Blocking
conditions.description: Checks whether a player is blocking with their shield.
conditions.examples: on damage of player:\n    victim is blocking\n    damage attacker by 0.5 hearts

conditions.name: Is Burning
conditions.description: Checks whether an entity is on fire, e.g. a zombie due to being in sunlight, or any entity after falling into lava.
conditions.examples: # increased attack against burning targets\nvictim is burning:\n    increase damage by 2

conditions.name: Is Charged
conditions.description: Checks if a creeper is charged (powered).
conditions.examples: if the last spawned creeper is charged:\n    broadcast "A charged creeper is at %location of last spawned creeper%"

conditions.name: Is Climbing
conditions.description: Whether a living entity is climbing, such as a spider up a wall or a player on a ladder.
conditions.examples:
spawn a spider at location of spawn
wait a second
if the last spawned spider is climbing:
    message"The spider is now climbing!"

conditions.name: Is Edible
conditions.description: Checks whether an item is edible.
conditions.examples: steak is edible\nplayer's tool is edible

conditions.name: Is Empty
conditions.description: Checks whether an inventory, an inventory slot, or a text is empty.
conditions.examples: player's inventory is empty

conditions.name: Is Enchanted
patterns: %item types% (isn't|is not|aren't|are not) enchanted [with %enchantment type%]
conditions.description: Checks whether an item is enchanted.
conditions.examples: tool of the player is enchanted with efficiency 2\nhelm, chestplate, leggings or boots are enchanted

conditions.name: Is Flammable
conditions.description: Checks whether an item is flammable.
conditions.examples: wood is flammable\nplayer's tool is flammable

conditions.name: Is Flying
conditions.description: Checks whether a player is flying.
conditions.examples: player is not flying

conditions.name: Is Frozen
conditions.description: Checks whether an entity is frozen.
conditions.examples: if player is frozen:\n    kill player

conditions.name: Is Fuel
conditions.description: Checks whether an item can be used as fuel in a furnace.
conditions.examples:
on right click on furnace:
    if player's tool is not fuel:
        send "Please hold a valid fuel item in your hand"
        cancel event

conditions.name: Is Gliding
conditions.description: Checks whether a living entity is gliding.
conditions.examples: if player is gliding

conditions.name: Is Holding
patterns: [%living entities%] ha(s|ve) %item types% in [main] hand
[%living entities%] (is|are) holding %item types% [in main hand]
[%living entities%] ha(s|ve) %item types% in off[(-| )]hand
[%living entities%] (is|are) holding %item types% in off[(-| )]hand
[%living entities%] (ha(s|ve) not|do[es]n't have) %item types% in [main] hand
[%living entities%] (is not|isn't) holding %item types% [in main hand]
[%living entities%] (ha(s|ve) not|do[es]n't have) %item types% in off[(-| )]hand
[%living entities%] (is not|isn't) holding %item types% in off[(-| )]hand
conditions.description: Checks whether a player is holding a specific item. Cannot be used with endermen, use 'entity is [not] an enderman holding <item type>' instead.
conditions.examples: player is holding a stick\nvictim isn't holding a sword of sharpness

conditions.name: Is Incendiary
patterns: %entities% ((is not|are not|isn't|aren't) incendiary|(does not|do not|doesn't|don't) cause[s] a[n] (incendiary|fiery) explosion)
conditions.description: Checks if an entity will create fire when it explodes. This condition is also usable in an explosion prime event.
conditions.examples: on explosion prime:\n    if the explosion is fiery:\n        broadcast "A fiery explosive has been ignited!"

conditions.name: Is Interactable
conditions.description: Checks wether or not a block is interactable.
conditions.examples:
on block break:
    if event-block is interactable:
        cancel event
        send "You cannot break interactable blocks!"

conditions.name: Is Invisible
conditions.description: Checks whether a living entity is invisible.
conditions.examples: target entity is invisible

conditions.name: Is Invulnerable
conditions.description: Checks whether an entity is invulnerable.
conditions.examples: target entity is invulnerable

conditions.name: Is Jumping
conditions.description: Checks whether a living entity is jumping. This condition does not work on players.
conditions.examples:
on spawn of zombie:
    while event-entity is not jumping:
        wait 5 ticks
    push event-entity upwards

conditions.name: Is Leashed
conditions.description: Checks to see if an entity is currently leashed.
conditions.examples: target entity is leashed

conditions.name: Is Loaded
patterns: chunk [at] %number%, %number% (in|of) [world] %world% is[((n't| not))] loaded
conditions.description: Checks whether or not a chunk/world is loaded. 'chunk at 1, 1' uses chunk coords, which are location coords divided by 16.
conditions.examples: if chunk at {home::%player's uuid%} is loaded:\nif chunk 1, 10 in world "world" is loaded:\nif world("lobby") is loaded:

conditions.name: Is Member/Owner of Region
patterns: %offline players% (is|are) ([a] member|[(the|an)] owner) of [[the] region] %regions%
%offline players% (is|are)(n't| not) ([a] member|[(the|an)] owner) of [[the] region] %regions%
conditions.description:
Checks whether a player is a member or owner of a particular region.
This condition requires a supported regions plugin to be installed.
conditions.examples:
on region enter:
    player is the owner of the region
    message "Welcome back to %region%!"
    send "%player% just entered %region%!" to all members of the region

conditions.name: Is Normalized
conditions.description: Checks whether a vector is normalized i.e. length of 1
conditions.examples: vector of player's location is normalized

conditions.name: Is Occluding
conditions.description: Checks whether an item is a block and completely blocks vision.
conditions.examples: player's tool is occluding

conditions.name: Is Online
conditions.description: Checks whether a player is online.
conditions.examples: player is online\nplayer-argument is offline

conditions.name: Is Operator
conditions.description: Checks whether a player is a server operator.
conditions.examples: player is an operator

conditions.name: Is Passable
conditions.description:
Checks whether a block is passable.
A block is passable if it has no colliding parts that would prevent players from moving through it.
Blocks like tall grass, flowers, signs, etc. are passable, but open doors, fence gates, trap doors, etc. are not because they still have parts that can be collided with.
conditions.examples: if player's targeted block is passable

conditions.name: Is Plugin Enabled
conditions.description:
Check if a plugin is enabled/disabled on the server.
Plugin names can be found in the plugin's 'plugin.yml' file or by using the '/plugins' command, they are NOT the name of the plugin's jar file.
When checking if a plugin is not enabled, this will return true if the plugin is either disabled or not on the server. 
When checking if a plugin is disabled, this will return true if the plugin is on the server and is disabled.

conditions.name: Is Poisoned
conditions.description: Checks whether an entity is poisoned.
conditions.examples: player is poisoned:\n    cure the player from poison\n    message "You have been cured!"

conditions.name: Is Preferred Tool
patterns: %item types% (is|are) %blocks/block datas%'s preferred tool[s]
%item types% (is|are) [the|a] preferred tool[s] (for|of) %blocks/block datas%
%item types% (is|are)(n't| not) %blocks/block datas%'s preferred tool[s]
%item types% (is|are)(n't| not) [the|a] preferred tool[s] (for|of) %blocks/block datas%
conditions.description: Checks whether an item is the preferred tool for a block. A preferred tool is one that will drop the block's item when used. For example, a wooden pickaxe is a preferred tool for grass and stone blocks, but not for iron ore.

conditions.name: Is Riding
conditions.description: Tests whether an entity is riding another or is in a vehicle.
conditions.examples: player is riding a saddled pig

conditions.name: Is Riptiding
conditions.description: Checks to see if an entity is currently using the Riptide enchantment.
conditions.examples: target entity is riptiding

conditions.name: Is Script Loaded
conditions.description: Check if the current script, or another script, is currently loaded.
conditions.examples: script is loaded\nscript "example.sk" is loaded

conditions.name: Is Silent
conditions.description: Checks whether an entity is silent i.e. its sounds are disabled.
conditions.examples: target entity is silent

conditions.name: Is Sleeping
conditions.description: Checks whether a player is sleeping.
conditions.examples:
# cut your enemies' throats in their sleep >=)
on attack:
    attacker is holding a sword
    victim is sleeping
    increase the damage by 1000

conditions.name: Is Slime Chunk
patterns: %chunk% (isn't|is not|aren't|are not) ([a] slime chunk|slime chunks|slimey)
conditions.description: Tests whether a chunk is a so-called slime chunk. Slimes can generally spawn in the swamp biome and in slime chunks. For more info, see the Minecraft wiki.

conditions.name: Is Sneaking
conditions.description: Checks whether a player is sneaking.
conditions.examples:
# prevent mobs from seeing sneaking players if they are at least 4 meters apart
on target:
    target is sneaking
    distance of target and the entity is bigger than 4
    cancel the event

conditions.name: Is Solid
conditions.description: Checks whether an item is solid.
conditions.examples: grass block is solid\nplayer's tool isn't solid

conditions.name: Is Sprinting
conditions.description: Checks whether a player is sprinting.
conditions.examples: player is not sprinting

conditions.name: Is Stackable
conditions.description: Checks whether an item is stackable.
conditions.examples: diamond axe is stackable\nbirch wood is stackable\ntorch is stackable

conditions.name: Is Swimming
conditions.description: Checks whether a living entity is swimming.
conditions.examples: player is swimming

conditions.name: Is Tameable
conditions.description: Check if an entity is tameable.
conditions.examples: on damage:\n    if victim is tameable:\n        cancel event

conditions.name: Is Transparent
conditions.description: Checks whether an item is transparent. Note that this condition may not work for all blocks, due to the transparency list used by Spigot not being completely accurate.
conditions.examples: player's tool is transparent.

conditions.name: Is Unbreakable
conditions.description: Checks whether an item is unbreakable.
conditions.examples: if event-item is unbreakable

conditions.name: Is Valid
conditions.description: Checks whether an entity has died or been despawned for some other reason.
conditions.examples: if event-entity is valid

conditions.name: Is Wearing
patterns: %living entities% (isn't|is not|aren't|are not) wearing %item types%
conditions.description: Checks whether a player is wearing some armour.
conditions.examples: player is wearing an iron chestplate and iron leggings\nplayer is wearing all diamond armour

conditions.name: Is Whitelisted
conditions.description: Whether or not the server or a player is whitelisted.
conditions.examples: if server is whitelisted:\nif player is whitelisted

conditions.name: Is Within
conditions.description: Whether a location is within something else. The "something" can be a block, an entity, a chunk, a world, or a cuboid formed by two other locations. Note that using the is between condition will refer to a straight line between locations, while this condition will refer to the cuboid between locations.

conditions.name: Is Within Radius
conditions.description: Checks whether a location is within a certain radius of another location.
conditions.examples:
on damage:
    if attacker's location is within 10 blocks around {_spawn}:
        cancel event
        send "You can't PVP in spawn."

conditions.name: Is a Skript command
conditions.description: Checks whether a command/string is a custom Skript command.
conditions.examples:
# Example 1
on command:
    command is a skript command

# Example 2
"sometext" is a skript command

conditions.name: Is of Type
patterns: %item stacks/entities% (is|are) of type[s] %entity types/entity types%
%item stacks/entities% (isn't|is not|aren't|are not) of type[s] %entity types/entity types%
conditions.description: Checks whether an item of an entity is of the given type. This is mostly useful for variables, as you can use the general 'is' condition otherwise (e.g. 'victim is a creeper').
conditions.examples: tool is of type {selected type}\nvictim is of type {villager type}

conditions.name: Is on Ground
conditions.description: Checks whether an entity is on ground.
conditions.examples: player is not on ground

conditions.name: Left Handed
conditions.description:
Checks if living entities or players are left or right-handed. Armor stands are neither right nor left-handed.
Paper 1.17.1+ is required for non-player entities.
conditions.examples: on damage of player:\n    if victim is left handed:\n        cancel event

conditions.name: Matches
patterns: %texts% (partially match[es]|do[es](n't| not) partially match) %texts%
conditions.description: Checks whether the defined strings match the input regexes (Regular expressions).

conditions.name: Method Exists
conditions.description: Checks if a method exists
conditions.examples: if method "org.bukkit.Bukkit#getPluginCommand(java.lang.String)

conditions.name: Projectile Can Bounce
conditions.description: Whether or not a projectile can bounce.
conditions.examples: on shoot:\n    send "Boing!" to all players if projectile can bounce

conditions.name: PvP
conditions.description: Checks the PvP state of a world.
conditions.examples: PvP is enabled\nPvP is disabled in "world"

conditions.name: Region Contains
conditions.description: Checks whether a location is contained in a particular region. This condition requires a supported regions plugin to be installed.

conditions.name: Resource Pack
conditions.description: Checks state of the resource pack in a resource pack request response event.
conditions.examples: on resource pack response:\n    if the resource pack wasn't accepted:\n        kick the player due to "You have to install the resource pack to play in this server!"

conditions.name: Running Minecraft
conditions.description: Checks if current Minecraft version is given version or newer.
conditions.examples: running minecraft "1.14"

conditions.name: Starts/Ends With
conditions.description: Checks if a text starts or ends with another.
conditions.examples: if the argument starts with "test" or "debug":\n    send "Stop!"

conditions.name: Time
patterns: %date% (was|were)( more|(n't| not) less) than %time span% [ago]
%date% (was|were)((n't| not) more| less) than %time span% [ago]
conditions.description: Tests whether a given real time was more or less than some time span ago.
conditions.examples:
command /command-with-cooldown:
    trigger:
        {command::%player's uuid%::last-usage} was less than a minute ago:
            message "Please wait a minute between uses of this command."
            stop
        set {command::%player's uuid%::last-usage} to now
        # ... actual command trigger here ...

effects.name: Action Bar
effects.description: Sends an action bar message to the given player(s).
effects.examples: send action bar "Hello player!" to player

effects.name: Ban
patterns: ban %texts/offline players% [(by reason of|because [of]|on account of|due to) %text%] [for %time span%]
ban %players% by IP [(by reason of|because [of]|on account of|due to) %text%] [for %time span%]
IP(-| )ban %players% [(by reason of|because [of]|on account of|due to) %text%] [for %time span%]
effects.description: Bans or unbans a player or an IP address. If a reason is given, it will be shown to the player when they try to join the server while banned. A length of ban may also be given to apply a temporary ban. If it is absent for any reason, a permanent ban will be used instead. We recommend that you test your scripts so that no accidental permanent bans are applied. Note that banning people does not kick them from the server. Consider using the kick effect after applying a ban.
effects.examples:
unban player
ban "127.0.0.1"
IP-ban the player because "he is an idiot"
ban player due to "inappropriate language" for 2 days

effects.name: Break Block
effects.description:
Breaks the block and spawns items as if a player had mined it

You can add a tool, which will spawn items based on how that tool would break the block 
(ie: When using a hand to break stone, it drops nothing, whereas with a pickaxe it drops cobblestone)
effects.examples:
on right click:
    break clicked block naturally
loop blocks in radius 10 around player:
    break loop-block using player's tool
loop blocks in radius 10 around player:
    break loop-block naturally using diamond pickaxe

effects.name: Broadcast
effects.description: Broadcasts a message to the server.
effects.examples: broadcast "Welcome %player% to the server!"\nbroadcast "Woah! It's a message!"

effects.name: Cancel Command Cooldown
effects.description: Only usable in commands. Makes it so the current command usage isn't counted towards the cooldown.
effects.examples:
command /nick &lt;text&gt;:
    executable by: players
    cooldown: 10 seconds
    trigger:
        if length of arg-1 is more than 16:
            # Makes it so that invalid arguments don't make you wait for the cooldown again
            cancel the cooldown
            send "Your nickname may be at most 16 characters."
            stop
        set the player's display name to arg-1

effects.name: Cancel Drops
effects.description: Cancels drops of items or experiences in a death or block break event. Please note that this doesn't keep items or experiences of a dead player. If you want to do that, use the Keep Inventory / Experience effect.
effects.examples:
on death of a zombie:
    if name of the entity is "&cSpecial":
        cancel drops of items

on break of a coal ore:
    cancel the experience drops

effects.name: Cancel Event
effects.description: Cancels the event (e.g. prevent blocks from being placed, or damage being taken).
effects.examples:
on damage:
    victim is a player
    victim has the permission "skript.god"
    cancel the event

effects.name: Change: Set/Add/Remove/Delete/Reset
effects.description: A very general effect that can change many expressions. Many expressions can only be set and/or deleted, while some can have things added to or removed from them.
effects.examples:
# set:
Set the player's display name to "&lt;red&gt;%name of player%"
set the block above the victim to lava
# add:
add 2 to the player's health # preferably use '<a href='#EffHealth'>heal</a>' for this
add argument to {blacklist::*}
give a diamond pickaxe of efficiency 5 to the player
increase the data value of the clicked block by 1
# remove:
remove 2 pickaxes from the victim
subtract 2.5 from {points::%uuid of player%}
# remove all:
remove every iron tool from the player
remove all minecarts from {entitylist::*}
# delete:
delete the block below the player
clear drops
delete {variable}
# reset:
reset walk speed of player
reset chunk at the targeted block

effects.name: Charge Creeper
effects.description: Charges or uncharges a creeper. A creeper is charged when it has been struck by lightning.
effects.examples: on spawn of creeper:\n    charge the event-entity

effects.name: Color Items
effects.description: Colors items in a given color. You can also use RGB codes if you feel limited with the 16 default colors. RGB codes are three numbers from 0 to 255 in the order (red, green, blue), where (0,0,0) is black and (255,255,255) is white. Armor is colorable for all Minecraft versions. With Minecraft 1.11 or newer you can also color potions and maps. Note that the colors might not look exactly how you'd expect.
effects.examples: dye player's helmet blue\ncolor the player's tool red

effects.name: Command
effects.description:
Executes a command. This can be useful to use other plugins in triggers.
If the command is a bungeecord side command, you can use the [bungeecord] option to execute command on the proxy.
effects.examples: make player execute command "/home"\nexecute console command "/say Hello everyone!"\nexecute player bungeecord command "/alert &6Testing Announcement!"

effects.name: Connect
effects.description: Connects a player to another bungeecord server
effects.examples: connect all players to "hub"

effects.name: Continue
effects.description: Immediately moves the (while) loop on to the next iteration.

effects.name: Damage/Heal/Repair
patterns: damage %living entities/item types% by %number% [heart[s]] [with fake cause %damage cause%]
effects.description: Damage/Heal/Repair an entity, or item.
effects.examples: damage player by 5 hearts\nheal the player\nrepair tool of player

effects.name: Delay
effects.description: Delays the script's execution by a given timespan. Please note that delays are not persistent, e.g. trying to create a tempban script with ban player → wait 7 days → unban player will not work if you restart your server anytime within these 7 days. You also have to be careful even when using small delays!
effects.examples: wait 2 minutes\nhalt for 5 minecraft hours\nwait a tick

effects.name: Do If
effects.description: Execute an effect if a condition is true.
effects.examples: on join:\n    give a diamond to the player if the player has permission "rank.vip"

effects.name: Drop
effects.description: Drops one or more items.
effects.examples: on death of creeper:\n    drop 1 TNT

effects.name: Enable/Disable/Reload Script File
effects.description: Enables, disables, or reloads a script file.
effects.examples: reload script "test"\nenable script file "testing"\nunload script file "script.sk"

effects.name: Enchant/Disenchant
effects.description: Enchant or disenchant an existing item.
effects.examples: enchant the player's tool with sharpness 5\ndisenchant the player's tool

effects.name: Equip
patterns: equip [%living entities%] with %item types%
make %living entities% wear %item types%
effects.description: Equips or unequips an entity with some given armor. This will replace any armor that the entity is wearing.
effects.examples:
equip player with diamond helmet
equip player with all diamond armor
unequip diamond chestplate from player
unequip all armor from player
unequip player's armor

effects.name: Exit
effects.description: Exits a given amount of loops and conditionals, or the entire trigger.
effects.examples:
if player has any ore:
    stop
message "%player% has no ores!"
loop blocks above the player:
    loop-block is not air:
        exit 2 sections
    set loop-block to water

effects.name: Explode Creeper
effects.description: Starts the explosion process of a creeper or instantly explodes it.
effects.examples: start explosion of the last spawned creeper\nstop ignition of the last spawned creeper

effects.name: Explosion
effects.description: Creates an explosion of a given force. The Minecraft Wiki has an article on explosions which lists the explosion forces of TNT, creepers, etc. Hint: use a force of 0 to create a fake explosion that does no damage whatsoever, or use the explosion effect introduced in Skript 2.0. Starting with Bukkit 1.4.5 and Skript 2.0 you can use safe explosions which will damage entities but won't destroy any blocks.
effects.examples: create an explosion of force 10 at the player\ncreate an explosion of force 0 at the victim

effects.name: Feed
effects.description: Feeds the specified players.
effects.examples: feed all players\nfeed the player by 5 beefs

effects.name: Force Attack
patterns: force %living entities% to attack %entity%
effects.description: Makes a living entity attack an entity with a melee attack.
effects.examples: spawn a wolf at player's location\nmake last spawned wolf attack player

effects.name: Force Respawn
effects.description: Forces player(s) to respawn if they are dead. If this is called without delay from death event, one tick is waited before respawn attempt.
effects.examples: on death of player:\n    force event-player to respawn

effects.name: Handedness
effects.description: Make mobs left or right-handed. This does not affect players.
effects.examples:
spawn skeleton at spawn of world "world":
    make entity left handed

make all zombies in radius 10 of player right handed

effects.name: Hide Player from Server List
effects.description: Hides a player from the hover list and decreases the online players count (only if the player count wasn't changed before).
effects.examples: on server list ping:\n    hide {vanished::*} from the server list

effects.name: Ignite/Extinguish
effects.description: Lights entities on fire or extinguishes them.
effects.examples: ignite the player\nextinguish the player

effects.name: Keep Inventory / Experience
effects.description: Keeps the inventory or/and experiences of the dead player in a death event.
effects.examples: on death of a player:\n    if the victim is an op:\n        keep the inventory and experiences

effects.name: Kick
patterns: kick %players% [(by reason of|because [of]|on account of|due to) %text%]
effects.description: Kicks a player from the server.
effects.examples: on place of TNT, lava, or obsidian:\n    kick the player due to "You may not place %block%!"\n    cancel the event

effects.name: Kill
effects.description:
Kills an entity.
Note: This effect does not set the entity's health to 0 (which causes issues), but damages the entity by 100 times its maximum health.
effects.examples: kill the player\nkill all creepers in the player's world\nkill all endermen, witches and bats

effects.name: Knockback
effects.description: Apply the same velocity as a knockback to living entities in a direction. Mechanics such as knockback resistance will be factored in.
effects.examples: knockback player north\nknock victim (vector from attacker to victim) with strength 10

effects.name: Launch firework
effects.description: Launch firework effects at the given location(s).
effects.examples: launch ball large colored red, purple and white fading to light green and black at player's location with duration 1

effects.name: Leash entities
effects.description: Leash living entities to other entities.
effects.examples: leash the player to the target entity

effects.name: Lightning
effects.description: Strike lightning at a given location. Can use 'lightning effect' to create a lightning that does not harm entities or start fires.
effects.examples: strike lightning at the player\nstrike lightning effect at the victim

effects.name: Load Server Icon
effects.description: Loads server icons from the given files. You can get the loaded icon using the last loaded server icon expression. Please note that the image must be 64x64 and the file path starts from the server folder.

effects.name: Locally Suppress Warning
effects.description: Suppresses target warnings from the current script.
effects.examples: locally suppress missing conjunction warnings\nsuppress the variable save warnings

effects.name: Log
effects.description:
Writes text into a .log file. Skript will write these files to /plugins/Skript/logs.
NB: Using 'server.log' as the log file will write to the default server log. Omitting the log file altogether will log the message as '[Skript] [<script>.sk] <message>' in the server log.
effects.examples: on place of TNT:\n    log "%player% placed TNT in %world% at %location of block%" to "tnt/placement.log"

effects.name: Look At
patterns: (force|make) %living entities% [to] (face [towards]|look [(at|towards)]) (%entity%['s (feet|eyes)]|(feet|eyes) of %entity%) [at [head] [rotation] speed %number%] [[and] max[imum] [head] pitch %number%]
(force|make) %living entities% [to] (face [towards]|look [(at|towards)]) %vector/location% [at [head] [rotation] speed %number%] [[and] max[imum] [head] pitch %number%]
effects.description: Forces the mob(s) or player(s) to look at an entity, vector or location. Vanilla max head pitches range from 10 to 50.
effects.examples:
force the head of the player to look towards event-entity's feet

on entity explosion:
    set {_player} to the nearest player
    {_player} is set
    distance between {_player} and the event-location is less than 15
    make {_player} look towards vector from the {_player} to location of the event-entity

force {_enderman} to face the block 3 meters above {_location} at head rotation speed 100.5 and max head pitch -40

effects.name: Make Egg Hatch
effects.description: Makes the egg hatch in a Player Egg Throw event.
effects.examples: on player egg throw:\n    # EGGS FOR DAYZ!\n    make the egg hatch

effects.name: Make Fly
effects.description: Forces a player to start/stop flying.
effects.examples: make player fly\nforce all players to stop flying

effects.name: Make Incendiary
effects.description: Sets if an entity's explosion will leave behind fire. This effect is also usable in an explosion prime event.
effects.examples: on explosion prime:\n    make the explosion fiery

effects.name: Make Invisible
effects.description:
Makes a living entity visible/invisible. This is not a potion and therefore does not have features such as a time limit or particles.
When setting an entity to invisible while using an invisibility potion on it, the potion will be overridden and when it runs out the entity keeps its invisibility.
effects.examples: make target entity invisible

effects.name: Make Invulnerable
effects.description: Makes an entity invulnerable/not invulnerable.
effects.examples: make target entity invulnerable

effects.name: Make Say
effects.description: Forces a player to send a message to the chat. If the message starts with a slash it will force the player to use command.
effects.examples: make the player say "Hello."\nforce all players to send the message "I love this server"

effects.name: Message
effects.description: Sends a message to the given player. Only styles written in given string or in formatted expressions will be parsed. Adding an optional sender allows the messages to be sent as if a specific player sent them. This is useful with Minecraft 1.16.4's new chat ignore system, in which players can choose to ignore other players, but for this to work, the message needs to be sent from a player.
effects.examples:
message "A wild %player% appeared!"
message "This message is a distraction. Mwahaha!"
send "Your kill streak is %{kill streak::%uuid of player%}%." to player
if the targeted entity exists:
    message "You're currently looking at a %type of the targeted entity%!"
on chat:
    cancel event
    send "[%player%] >> %message%" to all players from player

effects.name: Open Book
effects.description: Opens a written book to a player.
effects.examples: open book player's tool to player

effects.name: Open/Close Inventory
effects.description:
Opens an inventory to a player. The player can then access and modify the inventory as if it was a chest that he just opened.
Please note that currently 'show' and 'open' have the same effect, but 'show' will eventually show an unmodifiable view of the inventory in the future.
effects.examples: show the victim's inventory to the player\nopen the player's inventory for the player

effects.name: Pathfind
patterns: make %living entities% (pathfind|move) to[wards] %living entity/location% [at speed %number%]
effects.description: Make an entity pathfind towards a location or another entity. Not all entities can pathfind. If the pathfinding target is another entity, the entities may or may not continuously follow the target.
effects.examples: make all creepers pathfind towards player\nmake all cows stop pathfinding\nmake event-entity pathfind towards player at speed 1

effects.name: Play Effect
effects.description: Plays a visual effect at a given location or on a given entity. Please note that some effects can only be played on entities, e.g. wolf hearts or the hurt effect, and that these are always visible to all players.
effects.examples: play wolf hearts on the clicked wolf\nshow mob spawner flames at the targeted block to the player

effects.name: Play Sound
patterns: play sound[s] %texts% [(in|from) %sound category%] [(at|with) volume %number%] [(and|at|with) pitch %number%] at %locations% [(to|for) %players%]
play sound[s] %texts% [(in|from) %sound category%] [(at|with) volume %number%] [(and|at|with) pitch %number%] [(to|for) %players%] [(at|from) %locations%]
effects.description: Plays a sound at given location for everyone or just for given players, or plays a sound to specified players. Both Minecraft sound names and Spigot sound names are supported. Playing resource pack sounds are supported too. The sound category is 'master' by default. Please note that sound names can get changed in any Minecraft or Spigot version, or even removed from Minecraft itself.
effects.examples: play sound "block.note_block.pling" # It is block.note.pling in 1.12.2\nplay sound "entity.experience_orb.pickup" with volume 0.5 to the player\nplay sound "custom.music.1" in jukebox category at {speakerBlock}

effects.name: Player Info Visibility
effects.description: Sets whether all player related information is hidden in the server list. The Vanilla Minecraft client will display ??? (dark gray) instead of player counts and will not show the hover hist when hiding player info. The version string can override the ???. Also the Online Players Count and Max Players expressions will return -1 when hiding player info.
effects.examples: hide player info\nhide player related information in the server list\nreveal all player related info

effects.name: Player Visibility
effects.description: Change visibility of a player for the given players. When reveal is used in combination of the hidden players expression and the viewers are not specified, this will default it to the given player in the hidden players expression. Note: if a player was hidden and relogs, this player will be visible again.

effects.name: Poison/Cure
effects.description: Poison or cure a creature.
effects.examples: poison the player\npoison the victim for 20 seconds\ncure the player from poison

effects.name: Potion Effects
patterns: apply %potion effects% to %living entities%
apply [potion of] %potions% [potion] [[[of] tier] %number%] to %living entities% [for %time span%] [(replacing [the] existing effect)]
apply ambient [potion of] %potions% [potion] [[[of] tier] %number%] to %living entities% [for %time span%] [(replacing [the] existing effect)]
apply [potion of] %potions% [potion] [[[of] tier] %number%] without [any] particles to %living entities% [for %time span%] [(replacing [the] existing effect)]
effects.since: 2.0, 2.2-dev27 (ambient and particle-less potion effects), 2.5 (replacing existing effect), 2.5.2 (potion effects)
effects.description: Apply or remove potion effects to/from entities.
effects.examples:
apply swiftness 2 to the player
remove haste from the victim
on join:
    apply potion of strength of tier {strength.%player%} to the player for 999 days
apply potion effects of player's tool to player

effects.name: Push
effects.description: Push entities around.
effects.examples: push the player upwards\npush the victim downwards at speed 0.5

effects.name: PvP
effects.description: Set the PvP state for a given world.
effects.examples: enable PvP #(current world only)\ndisable PvP in all worlds

effects.name: Replace
patterns: replace [(all|every)] %texts% in %texts% with %text% [with case sensitivity]
replace [(all|every)] %texts% with %text% in %texts% [with case sensitivity]
replace first %texts% in %texts% with %text% [with case sensitivity]
replace first %texts% with %text% in %text% [with case sensitivity]
replace [(all|every)] %item types% in %inventories% with %item type%
replace [(all|every)] %item types% with %item type% in %inventories%
effects.since: 2.0, 2.2-dev24 (replace in multiple strings and replace items in inventory), 2.5 (replace first, case sensitivity)
effects.description: Replaces all occurrences of a given text with another text. Please note that you can only change variables and a few expressions, e.g. a message or a line of a sign.
effects.examples:
replace "<item>" in {textvar} with "%item%"
replace every "&" with "§" in line 1
# The following acts as a simple chat censor, but it will e.g. censor mass, hassle, assassin, etc. as well:
on chat:
    replace all "kys", "idiot" and "noob" with "****" in the message
 
replace all stone and dirt in player's inventory and player's top inventory with diamond

effects.name: Return
effects.description: Makes a function return a value

effects.name: Send Block Change
patterns: make %players% see %blocks% as %item type/block data%
effects.description: Makes a player see a block as something it really isn't. BlockData support is only for MC 1.13+
effects.examples: make player see block at player as dirt\nmake player see target block as campfire[facing=south]

effects.name: Send Resource Pack
patterns: send [the] resource pack [from [[the] URL]] %text% to %players%
send [the] resource pack [from [[the] URL]] %text% with hash %text% to %players%
effects.description: Request that the player's client download and switch resource packs. The client will download the resource pack in the background, and will automatically switch to it once the download is complete. The URL must be a direct download link. The hash is used for caching, the player won't have to re-download the resource pack that way. The hash must be SHA-1, you can get SHA-1 hash of your resource pack using this online tool. The resource pack request action can be used to check status of the sent resource pack request.
effects.examples: on join:\n    send the resource pack from "URL" with hash "hash" to the player

effects.name: Shear
effects.description: Shears or 'un-shears' a sheep. Please note that no wool is dropped, this only sets the 'sheared' state of the sheep.
effects.examples: on rightclick on a sheep holding a sword:\n    shear the clicked sheep

effects.name: Shoot
patterns: shoot %entity types% [from %living entities/locations%] [(at|with) (speed|velocity) %number%] [%direction%]
(make|let) %living entities/locations% shoot %entity types% [(at|with) (speed|velocity) %number%] [%direction%]
effects.description: Shoots a projectile (or any other entity) from a given entity.
effects.examples: shoot an arrow\nmake the player shoot a creeper at speed 10\nshoot a pig from the creeper

effects.name: Silence Entity
effects.description: Controls whether or not an entity is silent.
effects.examples: make target entity silent

effects.name: Stop Server
effects.description: Stops or restarts the server. If restart is used when the restart-script spigot.yml option isn't defined, the server will stop instead.
effects.examples: stop the server\nrestart server

effects.name: Stop Sound
patterns: stop (all sound[s]|sound[s] %texts%) [(in|from) %sound category%] [(from playing to|for) %players%]
stop playing sound[s] %texts% [(in|from) %sound category%] [(to|for) %players%]
effects.description: Stops specific or all sounds from playing to a group of players. Both Minecraft sound names and Spigot sound names are supported. Resource pack sounds are supported too. The sound category is 'master' by default. A sound can't be stopped from a different category. Please note that sound names can get changed in any Minecraft or Spigot version, or even removed from Minecraft itself.
effects.examples:
stop sound "block.chest.open" for the player
stop playing sounds "ambient.underwater.loop" and "ambient.underwater.loop.additions" to the player
stop all sound for all players
stop sound in record category

effects.name: Swing Hand
effects.description: Makes an entity swing their hand. This does nothing if the entity does not have an animation for swinging their hand.
effects.examples: make player swing their main hand

effects.name: Teleport
effects.description:
Teleport an entity to a specific location. 
This effect is delayed by default on Paper, meaning certain syntax such as the return effect for functions cannot be used after this effect.
The keyword 'force' indicates this effect will not be delayed, 
which may cause lag spikes or server crashes when using this effect to teleport entities to unloaded chunks.
effects.examples: teleport the player to {homes.%player%}\nteleport the attacker to the victim

effects.name: Title - Reset
effects.description: Resets the title of the player to the default values.
effects.examples: reset the titles of all players\nreset the title

effects.name: Title - Send
patterns: send title %text% [with subtitle %text%] [to %players%] [for %time span%] [with fade[(-| )]in %time span%] [(and|with) fade[(-| )]out %time span%]
send subtitle %text% [to %players%] [for %time span%] [with fade[(-| )]in %time span%] [(and|with) fade[(-| )]out %time span%]
effects.description: Sends a title/subtitle to the given player(s) with optional fadein/stay/fadeout times for Minecraft versions 1.11 and above. If you're sending only the subtitle, it will be shown only if there's a title displayed at the moment, otherwise it will be sent with the next title. To show only the subtitle, use: send title " " with subtitle "yourtexthere" to player. Note: if no input is given for the times, it will keep the ones from the last title sent, use the reset title effect to restore the default values.
effects.examples:
send title "Competition Started" with subtitle "Have fun, Stay safe!" to player for 5 seconds
send title "Hi %player%" to player
send title "Loot Drop" with subtitle "starts in 3 minutes" to all players
send title "Hello %player%!" with subtitle "Welcome to our server" to player for 5 seconds with fadein 1 second and fade out 1 second
send subtitle "Party!" to all players

effects.name: Toggle
effects.description: Toggle the state of a block.
effects.examples:
# use arrows to toggle switches, doors, etc.
on projectile hit:
    projectile is arrow
    toggle the block at the arrow

effects.name: Toggle Flight
effects.description: Toggle the flight mode of a player.
effects.examples: allow flight to event-player

effects.name: Toggle Picking Up Items
patterns: allow %living entities% to pick([ ]up items| items up)
(forbid|disallow) %living entities% (from|to) pick([ing | ]up items|[ing] items up)
effects.description: Determines whether living entities are able to pick up items or not
effects.examples:
forbid player from picking up items
send "You can no longer pick up items!" to player

on drop:
    if player can't pick    up items:
        allow player to pick up items

effects.name: Tree
effects.description:
Creates a tree.
This may require that there is enough space above the given location and that the block below is dirt/grass, but it is possible that the tree will just grow anyways, possibly replacing every block in its path.
effects.examples: grow a tall redwood tree above the clicked block

effects.name: Vectors - Rotate Around Vector
patterns: rotate %vectors% around %vector% by %number% [degrees]
effects.description: Rotates a vector around another vector
effects.examples: rotate {_v} around vector 1, 0, 0 by 90

effects.name: Vectors - Rotate around XYZ
effects.description: Rotates a vector around x, y, or z axis by some degrees
