effects.examples: rotate {_v} around x-axis by 90\nrotate {_v} around y-axis by 90\nrotate {_v} around z-axis by 90 degrees

effects.name: Vehicle
effects.description: Makes an entity ride another entity, e.g. a minecart, a saddled pig, an arrow, etc.
effects.examples: make the player ride a saddled pig\nmake the attacker ride the victim

effects.name: op/deop
effects.description: Grant/revoke a user operator state.
effects.examples: op the player\ndeop all players

effects.name: Spawn
effects.description:
Spawn a creature. This can be used as an effect and as a section.
If it is used as a section, the section is run before the entity is added to the world.
You can modify the entity in this section, using for example 'event-entity' or 'cow'. 
Do note that other event values, such as 'player', won't work in this section.
effects.examples:
spawn 3 creepers at the targeted block
spawn a ghast 5 meters above the player
spawn a zombie at the player:
    set name of the zombie to ""

events.name: At Time
events.description: An event that occurs at a given minecraft time in every world or only in specific worlds.
events.examples: at 18:00\nat 7am in "world"

events.name: On Anvil Damage
events.description: Called when an anvil is damaged/broken from being used to repair/rename items.\nNote: this does not include anvil damage from falling.
events.examples: on anvil damage:\n    cancel the event

events.name: On Anvil Prepare
events.description: Called when an item is put in a slot for repair by an anvil. Please note that this event is called multiple times in a single item slot move.
events.examples:
on anvil prepare:
    event-item is set # result item
    chance of 5%:
        set repair cost to repair cost * 50%
        send "You're LUCKY! You got 50% discount." to player

events.name: On AoE Cloud Effect
events.description: Called when area effect cloud applies its potion effect. This happens every 5 ticks by default.
events.examples: on area cloud effect:

events.name: On Arm Swing
events.description: Called when a player swings his arm.
events.examples: on arm swing:\n    send "You swung your arm!"

events.name: On Armor Change
events.description: Called when armor pieces of a player are changed.
events.examples: on armor change:\n    send "You equipped %event-item%!"

events.name: On Bed Enter
events.description: Called when a player starts sleeping.
events.examples: on bed enter:

events.name: On Bed Leave
events.description: Called when a player leaves a bed.
events.examples: on player leaving a bed:

events.name: On Block Damage
events.description: Called when a player starts to break a block. You can usually just use the leftclick event for this.
events.examples: on block damaging:\n    if block is log:\n        send "You can't break the holy log!"

events.name: On Block Fertilize
events.description: Called when a player fertilizes blocks.
events.examples: on block fertilize:\n    send "Fertilized %size of fertilized blocks% blocks got fertilized."

events.name: On Block Growth
events.description: Called when a crop grows. Alternative to new form of generic grow event.
events.examples: on crop growth:

events.name: On Book Edit
events.description: Called when a player edits a book.
events.examples: on book edit:

events.name: On Book Sign
events.description: Called when a player signs a book.
events.examples: on book sign:

events.name: On Break / Mine
events.description: Called when a block is broken by a player. If you use 'on mine', only events where the broken block dropped something will call the trigger.
events.examples:
on mine:
on break of stone:
on mine of any ore:
on break of chest[facing=north]:
on break of potatoes[age=7]:

events.name: On Bucket Empty
events.description: Called when a player empties a bucket. You can also use the place event with a check for water or lava.
events.examples: on bucket empty:

events.name: On Bucket fill
events.description: Called when a player fills a bucket.
events.examples: on player filling a bucket:

events.name: On Burn
events.description: Called when a block is destroyed by fire.
events.examples: on burn:\non burn of wood, fences, or chests:\non burn of oak_log[axis=y]:

events.name: On Can Build Check
events.description: Called when a player rightclicks on a block while holding a block or a placeable item. You can either cancel the event to prevent the block from being built, or uncancel it to allow it.\nPlease note that the data value of the block to be placed is not available in this event, only its ID.
events.examples: on block can build check:\n    cancel event

events.name: On Chat
events.description: Called whenever a player chats.\nUse chat format to change message format.\nUse chat recipients to edit chat recipients.
events.examples:
on chat:
    if player has permission "owner":
        set chat format to "&amp;amp;lt;red&amp;amp;gt;[player]&amp;amp;lt;light gray&amp;amp;gt;: &amp;amp;lt;light red&amp;amp;gt;[message]"
    else if player has permission "admin":
        set chat format to "&amp;amp;lt;light red&amp;amp;gt;[player]&amp;amp;lt;light gray&amp;amp;gt;: &amp;amp;lt;orange&amp;amp;gt;[message]"
    else: #default message format
        set chat format to "&amp;amp;lt;orange&amp;amp;gt;[player]&amp;amp;lt;light gray&amp;amp;gt;: &amp;amp;lt;white&amp;amp;gt;[message]"

events.name: On Chunk Generate
events.description: Called after a new chunk was generated.
events.examples: on chunk generate:

events.name: On Chunk Load
events.description: Called when a chunk loads. The chunk might or might not contain mobs when it's loaded.
events.examples: on chunk load:

events.name: On Chunk Unload
events.description: Called when a chunk is unloaded due to not being near any player.
events.examples: on chunk unload:

events.name: On Click
patterns: [on] [(right|left)[( |-)]][mouse[( |-)]]click[ing] [on %entity type/item type%] [(with|using|holding) %item type%]
[on] [(right|left)[( |-)]][mouse[( |-)]]click[ing] (with|using|holding) %item type% on %entity type/item type%
events.description: Called when a user clicks on a block, an entity or air with or without an item in their hand.\nPlease note that rightclick events with an empty hand while not looking at a block are not sent to the server, so there's no way to detect them.\nAlso note that a leftclick on an entity is an attack and thus not covered by the 'click' event, but the 'damage' event.
events.examples:
on click:
on rightclick holding a fishing rod:
on leftclick on a stone or obsidian:
on rightclick on a creeper:
on click with a sword:

events.name: On Combust
events.description: Called when an entity is set on fire, e.g. by fire or lava, a fireball, or by standing in direct sunlight (zombies, skeletons).
events.examples: on combust:

events.name: On Command
events.description: Called when a player enters a command (not necessarily a Skript command) but you can check if command is a skript command, see Is a Skript command condition.
events.examples: on command:\non command "/stop":\non command "pm Njol ":

events.name: On Connect
events.description: Called when the player connects to the server. This event is called before the player actually joins the server, so if you want to prevent players from joining you should prefer this event over on join.
events.examples:
on connect:
    player doesn't have permission "VIP"
    number of players is greater than 15
    kick the player due to "The last 5 slots are reserved for VIP players."

events.name: On Consume
events.description: Called when a player is done eating/drinking something, e.g. an apple, bread, meat, milk or a potion.
events.examples: on consume:

events.name: On Craft
events.description: Called when a player crafts an item.
events.examples: on craft:

events.name: On Creeper Power
events.description: Called when a creeper is struck by lighting and gets powered. Cancel the event to prevent the creeper from being powered.
events.examples: on creeper power:

events.name: On Damage
events.description: Called when an entity receives damage, e.g. by an attack from another entity, lava, fire, drowning, fall, suffocation, etc.
events.examples: on damage:\non damage of a player:\non damage of player by zombie:

events.name: On Death
events.description: Called when a living entity (including players) dies.
events.examples:
on death:
on death of player:
on death of a wither or ender dragon:
    broadcast "A %entity% has been slain in %world%!"

events.name: On Dispense
events.description: Called when a dispenser dispenses an item.
events.examples: on dispense of iron block:\n    send "that'd be 19.99 please!"

events.name: On Drop
events.description: Called when a player drops an item from their inventory, or an entity drops an item, such as a chicken laying an egg.

events.name: On Egg Throw
events.description: Called when a player throws an egg and it lands. You can just use the shoot event in most cases. However, this event allows modification of properties like the hatched entity type and the number of entities to hatch.
events.examples: on throw of an egg:

events.name: On Enchant
events.description: Called when a player successfully enchants an item.\n To get the enchanted item, see the enchant item expression
events.examples: on enchant:\n    if the clicked button is 1: # offer 1\n        set the applied enchantments to sharpness 10 and unbreaking 10

events.name: On Enchant Prepare
events.description: Called when a player puts an item into enchantment table. This event may be called multiple times.\n To get the enchant item, see the enchant item expression
events.examples: on enchant prepare:\n    set enchant offer 1 to sharpness 1\n    set the cost of enchant offer 1 to 10 levels

events.name: On Enderman/Sheep/Silverfish/Falling Block
events.description: Called when an enderman places or picks up a block, a sheep eats grass, a silverfish boops into/out of a block or a falling block lands and turns into a block respectively.
events.examples:
on sheep eat:
    kill event-entity
    broadcast "A sheep stole some grass!"

on falling block land:
    event-entity is a falling dirt
    cancel event

events.name: On Entity Dismount
events.description: Called when an entity dismounts.
events.examples: on dismount:\n    kill event-entity

events.name: On Entity Jump
events.description: Called when an entity jumps.
events.examples: on entity jump:\n    if entity is a wither skeleton:\n        cancel event

events.name: On Entity Mount
events.description: Called when entity starts riding another.
events.examples: on mount:\n    cancel event

events.name: On Entity Portal
events.description: Called when an entity uses a nether or end portal. Cancel the event to prevent the entity from teleporting.
events.examples: on entity portal:\n    broadcast "A %type of event-entity% has entered a portal!

events.name: On Experience Change
events.description: Called when a player's experience changes.
events.examples: on level progress change:\n    set {_xp} to event-experience\n    broadcast "%{_xp}%"

events.name: On Experience Spawn
events.description: Called whenever experience is about to spawn.\nPlease note that this event will not fire for xp orbs spawned by plugins (including Skript) with Bukkit.
events.examples: on xp spawn:\n    world is "minigame_world"\n    cancel event

events.name: On Explode
events.description: Called when an entity (a primed TNT or a creeper) explodes.
events.examples: on explosion:

events.name: On Explosion Prime
events.description: Called when an explosive is primed, i.e. an entity will explode shortly. Creepers can abort the explosion if the player gets too far away, while TNT will explode for sure after a short time.
events.examples: on explosion prime:

events.name: On Fade
events.description: Called when a block 'fades away', e.g. ice or snow melts.
events.examples: on fade of snow or ice:\non fade of snow[layers=2]

events.name: On Firework Explode
events.description: Called when a firework explodes.
events.examples:
on firework explode
on firework exploding colored red, light green and black
on firework explosion colored light green:
    broadcast "A firework colored %colors% was exploded at %location%!"

events.name: On First Join
events.description: Called when a player joins the server for the first time.
events.examples: on first join:\n    broadcast "Welcome %player% to the server!"

events.name: On Fishing
events.description: Called when a player fishes something. This is not of much use yet.
events.examples: on fish:

events.name: On Flight Toggle
events.description: Called when a players stops/starts flying.
events.examples: on flight toggle:\n    if {game::%player%::playing} exists:\n        cancel event

events.name: On Flow
events.description: Called when a blocks flows or teleports to another block. This not only applies to water and lava, but teleporting dragon eggs as well.
events.examples: on block flow:\n    if event-block is water:\n        broadcast "Build more dams! It's starting to get wet in here"

events.name: On Form
events.description: Called when a block is created, but not by a player, e.g. snow forms due to snowfall, water freezes in cold biomes. This isn't called when block spreads (mushroom growth, water physics etc.), as it has its own event (see spread event).
events.examples: on form of snow:\non form of a mushroom:

events.name: On Fuel Burn
events.description: Called when a furnace burns an item from its fuel slot.
events.examples: on fuel burning:

events.name: On Gamemode Change
events.description: Called when a player's gamemode changes.
events.examples: on gamemode change:\non gamemode change to adventure:

events.name: On Gliding State Change
events.description: Called when an entity toggles glider on or off, or when server toggles gliding state of an entity forcibly.
events.examples: on toggling gliding:\n    cancel the event # bad idea, but you CAN do it!

events.name: On Grow
events.description: Called when a tree, giant mushroom or plant grows to next stage.
events.examples: on grow:\non grow of a tree:\non grow of a huge jungle tree:

events.name: On Hand Item Swap
events.description:
Called whenever a player swaps the items in their main- and offhand slots.
Works also when one or both of the slots are empty.
The event is called before the items are actually swapped,
so when you use the player's tool or player's offtool expressions,
they will return the values before the swap -
this enables you to cancel the event before anything happens.
events.examples: on swap hand items:\n    event-player's tool is a diamond sword\n    cancel event

events.name: On Heal
events.description: Called when an entity is healed, e.g. by eating (players), being fed (pets), or by the effect of a potion of healing (overworld mobs) or harm (nether mobs).
events.examples: on heal:

events.name: On Horse Jump
events.description: Called when a horse jumps.
events.examples: on horse jump:\n    push event-entity upwards at speed 2

events.name: On Hunger Meter Change
events.description: Called when the hunger bar of a player changes, i.e. either increases by eating or decreases over time.
events.examples: on food bar change:

events.name: On Ignition
events.description: Called when a block starts burning, i.e. a fire block is placed next to it and this block is flammable.\nThe burn event will be called when the block is about do be destroyed by the fire.
events.examples: on block ignite:\n    if event-block is a ladder:\n        cancel event

events.name: On Inventory Click
events.description: Called when clicking on inventory slot.
events.examples:
on inventory click:
    if event-item is stone:
        give player 1 stone
        remove 20$ from player's balance

events.name: On Inventory Close
events.description: Called when player's currently viewed inventory is closed.
events.examples: on inventory close:\n    if player's location is {location}:\n        send "You exited the shop!"

events.name: On Inventory Drag
events.description: Called when a player drags an item in their cursor across the inventory.
events.examples:
on inventory drag:
    if player's current inventory is {_gui}:
        send "You can't drag your items here!" to player
        cancel event

events.name: On Inventory Item Move
events.description: Called when an entity or block (e.g. hopper) tries to move items directly from one inventory to another.\nWhen this event is called, the initiator may have already removed the item from the source inventory and is ready to move it into the destination inventory.\nIf this event is cancelled, the items will be returned to the source inventory.
events.examples: on inventory item move:\n    broadcast "%holder of past event-inventory% is transporting %event-item% to %holder of event-inventory%!"

events.name: On Inventory Open
events.description: Called when an inventory is opened for player.
events.examples: on inventory open:\n    close player's inventory

events.name: On Inventory Pickup
events.description: Called when an inventory (a hopper, a hopper minecart, etc.) picks up an item
events.examples: on inventory pickup:

events.name: On Inventory Slot Change
events.description: Called when a slot in a player's inventory is changed.\nWarning: setting the event-slot to a new item can result in an infinite loop.
events.examples: on inventory slot change:\n    if event-item is a diamond:\n        send "You obtained a diamond!" to player

events.name: On Item Break
events.description: Called when a player breaks their tool because its damage reached the maximum value.\nThis event cannot be cancelled.
events.examples: on tool break:

events.name: On Item Damage
events.description: Called when an item is damaged. Most tools are damaged by using them; armor is damaged when the wearer takes damage.
events.examples: on item damage:\n    cancel event

events.name: On Item Despawn
events.description: Called when an item is about to be despawned from the world, usually 5 minutes after it was dropped.
events.examples: on item despawn of diamond:\n    send "Not my precious!"\n    cancel event

events.name: On Item Mend
events.description: Called when a player has an item repaired via the Mending enchantment.
events.examples:
on item mend:
    chance of 50%:
        cancel the event
        send "Oops! Mending failed!" to player

events.name: On Item Merge
events.description: Called when dropped items merge into a single stack. event-entity will be the entity which is trying to merge, and future event-entity will be the entity which is being merged into.
events.examples: on item merge of gold blocks:\n    cancel event

events.name: On Item Spawn
events.description: Called whenever an item stack is spawned in a world, e.g. as drop of a block or mob, a player throwing items out of their inventory, or a dispenser dispensing an item (not shooting it).
events.examples: on item spawn of iron sword:\n    broadcast "Someone dropped an iron sword!"

events.name: On Join
events.description: Called when the player joins the server. The player is already in a world when this event is called, so if you want to prevent players from joining you should prefer on connect over this event.
events.examples: on join:\n    message "Welcome on our awesome server!"\n    broadcast "%player% just joined the server!"

events.name: On Jump
events.description: Called whenever a player jumps.\nThis event requires PaperSpigot.
events.examples: on jump:\n    event-player does not have permission "jump"\n    cancel event

events.name: On Kick
events.description: Called when a player is kicked from the server. You can change the kick message or cancel the event entirely.
events.examples: on kick:

events.name: On Language Change
events.description: Called after a player changed their language in the game settings. You can use the language expression to get the current language of the player.\nThis event requires Minecraft 1.12+.
events.examples: on language change:\n    if player's language starts with "en":\n        send "Hello!"

events.name: On Leaves Decay
events.description: Called when a leaf block decays due to not being connected to a tree.
events.examples: on leaves decay:

events.name: On Level Change
events.description: Called when a player's level changes, e.g. by gathering experience or by enchanting something.
events.examples: on level change:

events.name: On Lightning Strike
events.description: Called when lightning strikes.
events.examples: on lightning:\n    spawn a zombie at location of event-entity

events.name: On Loot Generate
events.description: Called when a loot table of an inventory is generated in the world.\nFor example, when opening a shipwreck chest.
events.examples:
on loot generate:
    chance of 10%
    add 64 diamonds to the loot
    send "You hit the jackpot at %event-location%!"

events.name: On Move
events.description:
Called when a player or entity moves.
NOTE: Move event will only be called when the entity/player moves position, not orientation (ie: looking around).
NOTE: These events can be performance heavy as they are called quite often.
If you use these events, and later remove them, a server restart is recommended to clear registered events from Skript.

events.name: On Move On
events.description: Called when a player moves onto a certain type of block.\nPlease note that using this event can cause lag if there are many players online.
events.examples: on walking on dirt or grass:\non stepping on stone:

events.name: On Physics
events.description: Called when a physics check is done on a block. By cancelling this event you can prevent some things from happening, e.g. sand falling, dirt turning into grass, torches dropping if their supporting block is destroyed, etc.Please note that using this event might cause quite some lag since it gets called extremely often.
events.examples:
# prevents sand from falling
on block physics:
    block is sand
    cancel event

events.name: On Pick Up
events.description: Called when a player/entity picks up an item. Please note that the item is still on the ground when this event is called.
events.examples: on pick up:\non entity pickup of wheat:

events.name: On Pig Zap
events.description: Called when a pig is stroke by lightning and transformed into a zombie pigman. Cancel the event to prevent the transformation.
events.examples: on pig zap:

events.name: On Piston Extend
events.description: Called when a piston is about to extend.
events.examples: on piston extend:\n    broadcast "A piston is extending!"

events.name: On Piston Retract
events.description: Called when a piston is about to retract.
events.examples: on piston retract:\n    broadcast "A piston is retracting!"

events.name: On Place
events.description: Called when a player places a block.
events.examples: on place:\non place of a furnace, workbench or chest:\non break of chest[type=right] or chest[type=left]

events.name: On Player Chunk Enters
events.description: Called when a player enters a chunk. Note that this event is based on 'player move' event, and may be called frequent internally.
events.examples: on player enters a chunk:\n    send "You entered a chunk: %past event-chunk% -&amp;gt; %event-chunk%!" to player

events.name: On Player Deep Sleep
events.description: Called when a player has slept long enough to count as passing the night/storm.\nCancelling this event will prevent the player from being counted as deeply sleeping unless they exit and re-enter the bed.
events.examples: on player deep sleeping:\n    send "Zzzz.." to player

events.name: On Player Pickup Arrow
events.description: Called when a player picks up an arrow from the ground.
events.examples: on arrow pickup:\n    cancel the event\n    teleport event-projectile to block 5 above event-projectile

events.name: On Player Trade
events.description: Called when a player has traded with a villager.
events.examples:
on player trade:
    chance of 50%:
        cancel event
        send "The trade was somehow denied!" to player

events.name: On Player World Change
events.description: Called when a player enters a world. Does not work with other entities!
events.examples: on player world change:\n    world is "city"\n    send "Welcome to the City!"

events.name: On Portal
events.description: Called when a player uses a nether or end portal. Cancel the event to prevent the player from teleporting.
events.examples: on player portal:

events.name: On Portal Create
events.description: Called when a portal is created, either by a player or mob lighting an obsidian frame on fire, or by a nether portal creating its teleportation target in the nether/overworld.\nIn Minecraft 1.14+, you can use the player in this event.\nPlease note that there may not always be a player (or other entity) in this event.
events.examples: on portal create:

events.name: On Portal Enter
events.description: Called when an entity enters a nether portal or an end portal. Please note that this event will be fired many times for a nether portal.
events.examples: on portal enter:

events.name: On Prepare Craft
events.description: Called just before displaying crafting result to player. Note that setting the result item might or might not work due to Bukkit bugs.
events.examples: on preparing craft of torch:

events.name: On Pressure Plate / Trip
events.description: Called when a player steps on a pressure plate or tripwire respectively.
events.examples: on step on pressure plate:

events.name: On Projectile Collide
events.description: Called when a projectile collides with an entity.
events.examples: on projectile collide:\n    teleport shooter of event-projectile to event-entity

events.name: On Projectile Hit
events.description: Called when a projectile hits an entity or a block.\nUse the damage event with a check for a projectile to be able to use the entity that got hit in the case when the projectile hit a living entity.\nA damage event will even be fired if the damage is 0, e.g. when throwing snowballs at non-nether mobs.
events.examples: on projectile hit:\n    event-projectile is arrow\n    delete event-projectile

events.name: On Quit
events.description: Called when a player leaves the server.
events.examples: on quit:\non disconnect:

events.name: On Redstone
events.description: Called when the redstone current of a block changes. This event is of not much use yet.
events.examples: on redstone change:\n    send "someone is using redstone" to console

events.name: On Region Enter/Leave
events.description: Called when a player enters or leaves a region.\nThis event requires a supported regions plugin to be installed.
events.examples: on region exit:\n    message "Leaving %region%."

events.name: On Resource Pack Request Response
events.description: Called when a player takes action on a resource pack request sent via the send resource pack effect. The resource pack condition can be used to check the resource pack state. This event will be triggered once when the player accepts or declines the resource pack request, and once when the resource pack is successfully installed or failed to download.
events.examples:
on resource pack request response:
    if the resource pack was declined or failed to download:

on resource pack deny:
    kick the player due to "You have to install the resource pack to play in this server!"

events.name: On Respawn
events.description: Called when a player respawns. You should prefer this event over the death event as the player is technically alive when this event is called.
events.examples: on respawn:

events.name: On Resurrect Attempt
events.description: Called when an entity dies, always. If they are not holding a totem, this is cancelled - you can, however, uncancel it.
events.examples:
on resurrect attempt:
    entity is player
    entity has permission "admin.undying"
    uncancel the event

events.name: On Riptide
events.description: Called when the player activates the riptide enchantment, using their trident to propel them through the air.\nNote: the riptide action is performed client side, so manipulating the player in this event may have undesired effects.
events.examples: on riptide:\n    send "You are riptiding!"

events.name: On Script Load/Unload
events.description: Called directly after the trigger is loaded, or directly before the whole script is unloaded.\nThe keyword 'async' indicates the trigger can be ran asynchronously,
events.examples:
on load:
    set {running::%script%} to true
on unload:
    set {running::%script%} to false

events.name: On Server List Ping
events.description: Called when a server list ping is coming in, generally when a Minecraft client pings the server to show its information in the server list. The IP expression can be used to get the IP adress of the pinger. This event can be cancelled on PaperSpigot 1.12.2+ only and this means the player will see the server as offline (but still can join). Also you can use MOTD, Max Players, Online Players Count, Protocol Version, Version String, Hover List and Server Icon expressions, and Player Info Visibility and Hide Player from Server List effects to modify the server list.
events.examples:
on server list ping:
    set the motd to "Welcome %{player-by-IP::%ip%}%! Join now!" if {player-by-IP::%ip%} is set, else "Join now!"
    set the fake max players count to (online players count + 1)
    set the shown icon to a random server icon out of {server-icons::*}

events.name: On Server Start/Stop
events.description: Called when the server starts or stops (actually, when Skript starts or stops, so a /reload will trigger these events as well).
events.examples: on skript start:\non server stop:

events.name: On Sheep Regrow Wool
events.description: Called when sheep regrows its sheared wool back.
events.examples: on sheep grow wool:\n    cancel event

events.name: On Shoot
events.description: Called whenever a projectile is shot. Use the shooter expression to get who shot the projectile.
events.examples: on shoot:\n    if projectile is an arrow:\n        send "you shot an arrow!" to shooter

events.name: On Sign Change
events.description: As signs are placed empty, this event is called when a player is done editing a sign.
events.examples: on sign change:\n    line 2 is empty\n    set line 1 to "&amp;amp;lt;red&amp;amp;gt;%line 1%"

events.name: On Slime Split
events.description: Called when a slime splits. Usually this happens when a big slime dies.
events.examples: on slime split:

events.name: On Smelt
events.description: Called when a furnace smelts an item in its ore slot.
events.examples: on smelt:

events.name: On Sneak Toggle
events.description: Called when a player starts or stops sneaking. Use is sneaking to get whether the player was sneaking before the event was called.
events.examples:
# make players that stop sneaking jump
on sneak toggle:
    player is sneaking
    push the player upwards at speed 0.5

events.name: On Spawn
events.description: Called when an entity spawns (excluding players).
events.examples: on spawn of a zombie:\non spawn of an ender dragon:\n    broadcast "A dragon has been sighted in %world%!"

events.name: On Spawn Change
events.description: Called when the spawn point of a world changes.
events.examples: on spawn change:\n    broadcast "someone changed the spawn!"

events.name: On Spectate
events.description: Called with a player starts, stops or swaps spectating an entity.
events.examples: on player start spectating of a zombie:

events.name: On Sponge Absorb
events.description: Called when a sponge absorbs blocks.
events.examples: on sponge absorb:\n    loop absorbed blocks:\n        broadcast "%loop-block% was absorbed by a sponge"!

events.name: On Spread
events.description: Called when a new block forms as a result of a block that can spread, e.g. water or mushrooms.
events.examples: on spread:

events.name: On Sprint Toggle
events.description: Called when a player starts or stops sprinting. Use is sprinting to get whether the player was sprinting before the event was called.
events.examples: on sprint toggle:\n    player is not sprinting\n    send "Run!"

events.name: On Swim Toggle
events.description: Called when an entity swims or stops swimming.
events.examples: on swim toggle:\n    event-entity does not have permission "swim"\n    cancel event

events.name: On Tame
events.description: Called when a player tames a wolf or ocelot. Can be cancelled to prevent the entity from being tamed.
events.examples: on tame:

events.name: On Target
events.description: Called when a mob starts/stops following/attacking another entity, usually a player.
events.examples: on entity target:\n    target is a player

events.name: On Teleport
events.description: Called whenever a player is teleported, either by a nether/end portal or other means (e.g. by plugins).
events.examples: on teleport:

events.name: On Test Case
events.description: Contents represent one test case.
events.examples: Missing examples.

events.name: On Tool Change
events.description: Called whenever a player changes their held item by selecting a different slot (e.g. the keys 1-9 or the mouse wheel), not by dropping or replacing the item in the current slot.
events.examples: on player's held item change:

events.name: On Vehicle Create
events.description: Called when a new vehicle is created, e.g. when a player places a boat or minecart.
events.examples: on vehicle create:

events.name: On Vehicle Damage
events.description: Called when a vehicle gets damage. Too much damage will destroy the vehicle.
events.examples: on vehicle damage:

events.name: On Vehicle Destroy
events.description: Called when a vehicle is destroyed. Any passenger will be ejected and the vehicle might drop some item(s).
events.examples: on vehicle destroy:\n    cancel event

events.name: On Vehicle Enter
events.description: Called when an entity enters a vehicle, either deliberately (players) or by falling into them (mobs).
events.examples: on vehicle enter:\n    entity is a player\n    cancel event

events.name: On Vehicle Exit
events.description: Called when an entity exits a vehicle.
events.examples: on vehicle exit:\n    if event-entity is a spider:\n        kill event-entity

events.name: On Weather Change
events.description: Called when a world's weather changes.
events.examples: on weather change:\non weather change to sunny:

events.name: On World Init
events.description: Called when a world is initialised. As all default worlds are initialised before any scripts are loaded, this event is only called for newly created worlds.\nWorld management plugins might change the behaviour of this event though.
events.examples: on world init:

events.name: On World Load
events.description: Called when a world is loaded. As with the world init event, this event will not be called for the server's default world(s).
events.examples: on world load:\n    send "World is loading..." to console

events.name: On World Save
events.description: Called when a world is saved to disk. Usually all worlds are saved simultaneously, but world management plugins could change this.
events.examples: on world saving:\n    broadcast "World has been saved!"

events.name: On World Unload
events.description: Called when a world is unloaded. This event might never be called if you don't have a world management plugin.
events.examples: on world unload:\n    cancel event

events.name: On Zombie Break Door
events.description: Called when a zombie is done breaking a wooden door. Can be cancelled to prevent the zombie from breaking the door.
events.examples: on zombie breaking a wood door:

events.name: Periodical
events.description: An event that is called periodically.
events.examples:
every 2 seconds:
every minecraft hour:
every tick: # can cause lag depending on the code inside the event
every minecraft days:

events.name: Periodical
events.description: An event that is called periodically.
events.examples:
every 2 seconds in "world":
every minecraft hour in "flatworld":
every tick in "world": # can cause lag depending on the code inside the event
every minecraft days in "plots":

expressions.name: Absorbed blocks
expressions.description: The blocks absorbed by a sponge block.
expressions.examples: the absorbed blocks

expressions.name: Affected Entities
expressions.description: The affected entities in the area cloud effect event.
expressions.examples:
on area cloud effect:
    loop affected entities:
        if loop-value is a player:
            send "WARNING: you've step on an area effect cloud!" to loop-value

expressions.name: Age of Block/Entity
expressions.description:
Returns the age or maximum age of blocks and age for entities (there in no maximum age for entities).
For blocks, 'Age' represents the different growth stages that a crop-like block can go through. A value of 0 indicates that the crop was freshly planted, whilst a value equal to 'maximum age' indicates that the crop is ripe and ready to be harvested.
For entities, 'Age' represents the time left for them to become adults and it's in minus increasing to be 0 which means they're adults, e.g. A baby cow needs 20 minutes to become an adult which equals to 24,000 ticks so their age will be -24000 once spawned.
expressions.examples:
# Set targeted crop to fully grown crop
set age of targeted block to maximum age of targeted block
 
# Spawn a baby cow that will only need 1 minute to become an adult
spawn a baby cow at player
set age of last spawned entity to -1200 # in ticks = 60 seconds

expressions.name: All Banned Players/IPs
expressions.description: Obtains the list of all banned players or IP addresses.
expressions.examples: command /banlist:\n    trigger:\n        send all the banned players

expressions.name: All Groups
expressions.description: All the groups a player can have. This expression requires Vault and a compatible permissions plugin to be installed.
expressions.examples:
command /group &lt;text&gt;:
    trigger:
        if argument is "list":
            send "%all groups%"

expressions.name: All Operators
expressions.description: The list of operators on the server.
expressions.examples: set {_ops::*} to all operators

expressions.name: All Permissions
expressions.description: Returns all permissions of the defined player(s). Note that the modifications to resulting list do not actually change permissions.
expressions.examples: set {_permissions::*} to all permissions of the player

expressions.name: All Scripts
expressions.description: Returns all of the scripts, or just the enabled or disabled ones.
expressions.examples:
command /scripts:
    trigger:
        send "All Scripts: %scripts%" to player
        send "Loaded Scripts: %enabled scripts%" to player
        send "Unloaded Scripts: %disabled scripts%" to player

expressions.name: All commands
expressions.description: Returns all registered commands or all script commands.
expressions.examples: send "Number of all commands: %size of all commands%"\nsend "Number of all script commands: %size of all script commands%"

expressions.name: Alphabetical Sort
expressions.description: Sorts given strings in alphabetical order.
expressions.examples: set {_list::*} to alphabetically sorted {_strings::*}

expressions.name: Altitude
expressions.description: Effectively an alias of 'y-coordinate of …', it represents the height of some object above bedrock.
expressions.examples: on damage:\n    altitude of the attacker is higher than the altitude of the victim\n    set damage to damage * 1.2

expressions.name: Amount
expressions.description:
The amount of something. Please note that amount of %items% will not return the number of items, but the number of stacks, e.g. 1 for a stack of 64 torches. To get the amount of items in a stack, see the item amount expression. Also, you can get the recursive size of a list, which will return the recursive size of the list with sublists included, e.g. 
{list::*} Structure

  ├──── {list::1}: 1

  ├──── {list::2}: 2

  │     ├──── {list::2::1}: 3

  │     │    └──── {list::2::1::1}: 4

  │     └──── {list::2::2}: 5

  └──── {list::3}: 6
Where using %size of {list::*}% will only return 3 (the first layer of indices only), while %recursive size of {list::*}% will return 6 (the entire list) Please note that getting a list's recursive size can cause lag if the list is large, so only use this expression if you need to!
expressions.examples: message "There are %number of all players% players online!"

expressions.name: Amount of Items
expressions.description: Counts how many of a particular item type are in a given inventory.
expressions.examples: message "You have %number of ores in the player's inventory% ores in your inventory."

expressions.name: Anvil Repair Cost
expressions.description:
Returns the experience cost (in levels) to complete the current repair or the maximum experience cost (in levels) to be allowed by the current repair.
The default value of max cost set by vanilla Minecraft is 40.
expressions.examples:
on inventory click:
    if {AnvilRepairSaleActive} = true:
        wait a tick # recommended, to avoid client bugs
        set anvil repair cost to anvil repair cost * 50%
        send "Anvil repair sale is ON!" to player

on inventory click:
    player have permission "anvil.repair.max.bypass"
    set max repair cost of event-inventory to 99999

expressions.name: Anvil Text Input
expressions.description: An expression to get the name to be applied to an item in an anvil inventory.
expressions.examples:
on inventory click:
    type of event-inventory is anvil inventory
    if the anvil input text of the event-inventory is "FREE OP":
        ban player

expressions.name: Applied Enchantments
expressions.description:
The applied enchantments in an enchant event.
 Deleting or removing the applied enchantments will prevent the item's enchantment.
expressions.examples: on enchant:\n    set the applied enchantments to sharpness 10 and fire aspect 5

expressions.name: Argument
expressions.description:
Usable in script commands and command events. Holds the value of an argument given to the command, e.g. if the command "/tell <player> <text>" is used like "/tell Njol Hello Njol!" argument 1 is the player named "Njol" and argument 2 is "Hello Njol!".
One can also use the type of the argument instead of its index to address the argument, e.g. in the above example 'player-argument' is the same as 'argument 1'.
Please note that specifying the argument type is only supported in script commands.
expressions.examples:
give the item-argument to the player-argument
damage the player-argument by the number-argument
give a diamond pickaxe to the argument
add argument 1 to argument 2
heal the last argument

expressions.name: Arithmetic
expressions.description: Arithmetic expressions, e.g. 1 + 2, (health of player - 2) / 3, etc.
expressions.examples:
set the player's health to 10 - the player's health
loop (argument + 2) / 5 times:
    message "Two useless numbers: %loop-num * 2 - 5%, %2^loop-num - 1%"
message "You have %health of player * 2% half hearts of HP!"

expressions.name: Armour Slot
expressions.description: A part of a player's armour, i.e. the boots, leggings, chestplate or helmet.
expressions.examples: set chestplate of the player to a diamond chestplate\nhelmet of player is neither a helmet nor air # player is wearing a block, e.g. from another plugin

expressions.name: Arrow Attached Block
expressions.description: Returns the attached block of an arrow.
expressions.examples: set hit block of last shot arrow to diamond block

expressions.name: Arrow Knockback Strength
expressions.description: An arrow's knockback strength.
expressions.examples: on shoot:\n    event-projectile is an arrow\n    set arrow knockback strength of event-projectile to 10

expressions.name: Arrows Stuck
patterns: [number of] arrow[s] stuck in %living entities%
expressions.description: The number of arrows stuck in a living entity.
expressions.examples: set arrows stuck in player to 5

expressions.name: Attack Cooldown
expressions.description:
Returns the current cooldown for a player's attack. This is used to calculate damage, with 1.0 representing a fully charged attack and 0.0 representing a non-charged attack.
NOTE: Currently this can not be set to anything.
expressions.examples:
on damage:
    if attack cooldown of attacker < 1:
        set damage to 0
        send "Your hit was too weak! wait until your weapon is fully charged next time." to attacker

expressions.name: Attacked
expressions.description: The victim of a damage event, e.g. when a player attacks a zombie this expression represents the zombie. When using Minecraft 1.11+, this also covers the hit entity in a projectile hit event.
expressions.examples: on damage:\n    victim is a creeper\n    damage the attacked by 1 heart

expressions.name: Attacker
expressions.description:
The attacker of a damage event, e.g. when a player attacks a zombie this expression represents the player.
Please note that the attacker can also be a block, e.g. a cactus or lava, but this expression will not be set in these cases.
expressions.examples:
on damage:
    attacker is a player
    health of attacker is less than or equal to 2
    damage victim by 1 heart

expressions.name: Bed
expressions.description: Returns the bed location of a player, i.e. the spawn point of a player if they ever slept in a bed and the bed still exists and is unobstructed however, you can set the unsafe bed location of players and they will respawn there even if it has been obstructed or doesn't exist anymore and that's the default behavior of this expression otherwise you will need to be specific i.e. safe bed location. NOTE: Offline players can not have their bed location changed, only online players.

expressions.name: Biome
expressions.description: The biome at a certain location. Please note that biomes are only defined for x/z-columns (i.e. the altitude (y-coordinate) doesn't matter), up until Minecraft 1.15.x. As of Minecraft 1.16, biomes are now 3D (per block vs column).
expressions.examples:
# damage player in deserts constantly
every real minute:
    loop all players:
        biome at loop-player is desert
        damage the loop-player by 1

expressions.name: Block
expressions.description:
The block involved in the event, e.g. the clicked block or the placed block.
Can optionally include a direction as well, e.g. 'block above' or 'block in front of the player'.
expressions.examples:
block is ore
set block below to air
spawn a creeper above the block
loop blocks in radius 4:
    loop-block is obsidian
    set loop-block to water
block is a chest:
    clear the inventory of the block

expressions.name: Block
expressions.description:
The block involved in the event, e.g. the clicked block or the placed block.
Can optionally include a direction as well, e.g. 'block above' or 'block in front of the player'.
expressions.examples:
block is ore
set block below to air
spawn a creeper above the block
loop blocks in radius 4:
    loop-block is obsidian
    set loop-block to water
block is a chest:
    clear the inventory of the block

expressions.name: Block Break Speed
expressions.description: Gets the speed at which the given player would break this block, taking into account tools, potion effects, whether or not the player is in water, enchantments, etc. The returned value is the amount of progress made in breaking the block each tick. When the total breaking progress reaches 1.0, the block is broken. Note that the break speed can change in the course of breaking a block, e.g. if a potion effect is applied or expires, or the player jumps/enters water.
expressions.examples: on left click using diamond pickaxe:\n    event-block is set\n    send "Break Speed: %break speed for player%" to player

expressions.name: Block Data
expressions.description: Get the block data associated with a block. This data can also be used to set blocks.
expressions.examples: set {data} to block data of target block\nset block at player to {data}\nset block data of target block to oak_stairs[facing=south;waterlogged=true]

expressions.name: Block Hardness
expressions.description: Obtains the block's hardness level (also known as "strength"). This number is used to calculate the time required to break each block.
expressions.examples: set {_hard} to block hardness of target block\nif block hardness of target block > 5:

expressions.name: Block Sphere
patterns: [(all [[of] the]|the)] blocks around %location% in radius %number%
expressions.description: All blocks in a sphere around a center, mostly useful for looping.
expressions.examples: loop blocks in radius 5 around the player:\n    set loop-block to air

expressions.name: Blocks
expressions.description:
Blocks relative to other blocks or between other blocks. Can be used to get blocks relative to other blocks or for looping.
Blocks from/to and between will return a straight line whereas blocks within will return a cuboid.
expressions.examples:
loop blocks above the player:
loop blocks between the block below the player and the targeted block:
set the blocks below the player, the victim and the targeted block to air
set all blocks within {loc1} and {loc2} to stone
set all blocks within chunk at player to air

expressions.name: Blocks in Region
expressions.description: All blocks in a region. This expression requires a supported regions plugin to be installed.
expressions.examples: loop all blocks in the region {arena.%{faction.%player%}%}:\n    clear the loop-block

expressions.name: Book Author
expressions.description: The author of a book.
expressions.examples: on book sign:\n    message "Book Title: %author of event-item%"

expressions.name: Book Pages
patterns: [all [[of] the]|the] [book] (pages|content) of %item types/item stacks%
[book] page %number% of %item types/item stacks%
%item types/item stacks%'[s] [book] page %number%
expressions.description:
The pages of a book (Supports Skript's chat format)
Note: In order to modify the pages of a new written book, you must have the title and author
of the book set. Skript will do this for you, but if you want your own, please set those values.
expressions.examples:
on book sign:
    message "Book Pages: %pages of event-item%"
    message "Book Page 1: %page 1 of event-item%"

set page 1 of player's held item to "Book writing"

expressions.name: Book Title
expressions.description: The title of a book.
expressions.examples: on book sign:\n    message "Book Title: %title of event-item%"

expressions.name: Burn/Cook Time
expressions.description: The time a furnace takes to burn an item in a fuel burn event. Can also be used to change the burn/cook time of a placed furnace.
expressions.examples: on fuel burn:\n    if fuel slot is coal:\n        set burning time to 1 tick

expressions.name: Case Text
expressions.description: Copy of given text in Lowercase, Uppercase, Proper Case, camelCase, PascalCase, Snake_Case, and Kebab-Case
expressions.examples:
"Oops!" in lowercase # oops!
"oops!" in uppercase # OOPS!
"hellO i'm steve!" in proper case # HellO I'm Steve!
"hellO i'm steve!" in strict proper case # Hello I'm Steve!
"spAwn neW boSs ()" in camel case # spAwnNeWBoSs()
"spAwn neW boSs ()" in strict camel case # spawnNewBoss()
"geneRate ranDom numBer ()" in pascal case # GeneRateRanDomNumBer()
"geneRate ranDom numBer ()" in strict pascal case # GenerateRandomNumber()
"Hello Player!" in snake case # Hello_Player!
"Hello Player!" in lower snake case # hello_player!
"Hello Player!" in upper snake case # HELLO_PLAYER!
"What is your name?" in kebab case # What-is-your-name?
"What is your name?" in lower kebab case # what-is-your-name?
"What is your name?" in upper kebab case # WHAT-IS-YOUR-NAME?

expressions.name: Chat Format
expressions.description: Can be used to get/retrieve the chat format. The sender of a message is represented by [player] or [sender], and the message by [message] or [msg].
expressions.examples: set the chat format to "&lt;yellow&gt;[player]&lt;light gray&gt;: &lt;green&gt;[message]"

expressions.name: Chat Recipients
expressions.description: Recipients of chat events where this is called.
expressions.examples: chat recipients

expressions.name: Chunk
expressions.description: Returns the chunk of a block, location or entity is in, or a list of the loaded chunks of a world.
expressions.examples: add the chunk at the player to {protected chunks::*}\nset {_chunks::*} to the loaded chunks of the player's world

expressions.name: Clicked Block/Entity/Inventory/Slot
patterns: [the] (clicked [enchant[ment]] (button|option)|clicked (block|%*item type/entity type%)|clicked slot|clicked inventory|click (type|action)|inventory action)
expressions.description: The clicked block, entity, inventory, inventory slot, inventory click type or inventory action.
expressions.examples: message "You clicked on a %type of clicked entity%!"\nif the clicked block is a chest:\n    show the inventory of the clicked block to the player

expressions.name: Color of
patterns: [the] colo[u]r[s] of %blocks/item types/entities/firework effects%
expressions.description: The color of an item, can also be used to color chat messages with "<%color of ...%>this text is colored!".
expressions.examples: on click on wool:\n    message "This wool block is <%color of block%>%color of block%<reset>!"\n    set the color of the block to black

expressions.name: Colored / Uncolored
expressions.description: Parses <color>s and, optionally, chat styles in a message or removes any colors and chat styles from the message. Parsing all chat styles requires this expression to be used in same line with the send effect.
expressions.examples:
on chat:
    set message to colored message # Safe; only colors get parsed
command /fade &lt;player&gt;:
    trigger:
        set display name of the player-argument to uncolored display name of the player-argument
command /format &lt;text&gt;:
    trigger:
        message formatted text-argument # Safe, because we're sending to whoever used this command

expressions.name: Command
expressions.description: The command that caused an 'on command' event (excluding the leading slash and all arguments)

expressions.name: Command Info
expressions.description: Get information about a command.
expressions.examples:
main name of command "skript"
description of command "help"
label of command "pl"
usage of command "help"
aliases of command "bukkit:help"
permission of command "/op"
command "op"'s permission message
command "sk"'s plugin owner

expressions.name: Command Sender
expressions.description: The player or the console who sent a command. Mostly useful in commands and command events. If the command sender is a command block, its location can be retrieved by using %block's location%
expressions.examples: make the command sender execute "/say hi!"\non command:\n    log "%executor% used command /%command% %arguments%" to "commands.log"

expressions.name: Compass Target
expressions.description: The location a player's compass is pointing at.

expressions.name: Console
expressions.description: Represents the server's console which can receive messages and execute commands
expressions.examples: execute console command "/stop"\nsend "message to console" to the console

expressions.name: Cooldown Time/Remaining Time/Elapsed Time/Last Usage/Bypass Permission
expressions.description:
Only usable in command events. Represents the cooldown time, the remaining time, the elapsed time,
the last usage date, or the cooldown bypass permission.
expressions.examples:
command /home:
    cooldown: 10 seconds
    cooldown message: You last teleported home %elapsed time% ago, you may teleport home again in %remaining time%.
    trigger:
        teleport player to {home::%player%}

expressions.name: Coordinate
expressions.description: Represents a given coordinate of a location.
expressions.examples: player's y-coordinate is smaller than 40:\n    message "Watch out for lava!"

expressions.name: Creature/Entity/Player/Projectile/Villager/Powered Creeper/etc.
expressions.description:
The entity involved in an event (an entity is a player, a creature or an inanimate object like ignited TNT, a dropped item or an arrow).
You can use the specific type of the entity that's involved in the event, e.g. in a 'death of a creeper' event you can use 'the creeper' instead of 'the entity'.
expressions.examples:
give a diamond sword of sharpness 3 to the player
kill the creeper
kill all powered creepers in the wolf's world
projectile is an arrow

expressions.name: Cursor Slot
expressions.description: The item which the player has on their cursor. This slot is always empty if player has no inventories open.
expressions.examples: cursor slot of player is dirt\nset cursor slot of player to 64 diamonds

expressions.name: Custom Chest Inventory
patterns: [a] [new] chest inventory (named|with name) %text% [with %number% row[s]]
[a] [new] chest inventory with %number% row[s] [(named|with name) %text%]
expressions.description: Returns a chest inventory with the given amount of rows and the name. Use the open inventory effect to open it.
expressions.examples: open chest inventory with 1 row named "test" to player\nset {_inventory} to chest inventory with 1 row

expressions.name: Custom Model Data
expressions.description: Get/set the CustomModelData tag for an item. (Value is an integer between 0 and 99999999)
expressions.examples: set custom model data of player's tool to 3\nset {_model} to custom model data of player's tool

expressions.name: Damage
expressions.description: How much damage is done in a damage event, possibly ignoring armour, criticals and/or enchantments. Can be changed (remember that in Skript '1' is one full heart, not half a heart).
expressions.examples: increase the damage by 2

expressions.name: Damage Cause
expressions.description: The damage cause of a damage event. Please click on the link for more information.
expressions.examples: damage cause is lava, fire or burning

expressions.name: Damage Value/Durability
expressions.description: The damage value/durability of an item.
expressions.examples: set damage value of player's tool to 10\nreset the durability of {_item}\nset durability of player's held item to 0

expressions.name: Damaged Item
expressions.description: Directly damages an item. In MC versions 1.12.2 and lower, this can be used to apply data values to items/blocks
expressions.examples:
give player diamond sword with damage value 100
set player's tool to diamond hoe damaged by 250
give player diamond sword with damage 700 named "BROKEN SWORD"
set {_item} to diamond hoe with damage value 50 named "SAD HOE"
set target block of player to wool with data value 1
set target block of player to potato plant with data value 7

expressions.name: Date Ago/Later
expressions.description: A date the specified timespan before/after another date.
expressions.examples: set {_yesterday} to 1 day ago\nset {_hourAfter} to 1 hour after {someOtherDate}\nset {_hoursBefore} to 5 hours before {someOtherDate}

expressions.name: Default Value
expressions.description: A shorthand expression for giving things a default value. If the first thing isn't set, the second thing will be returned.
expressions.examples: broadcast {score::%player's uuid%} otherwise "%player% has no score!"

expressions.name: Difference
expressions.description: The difference between two values, e.g. numbers, dates or times.
expressions.examples: if difference between {command::%player%::lastuse} and now is smaller than a minute:\n    message "You have to wait a minute before using this command again!"

expressions.name: Difficulty
expressions.description: The difficulty of a world.
expressions.examples: set the difficulty of "world" to hard

expressions.name: Direction
patterns: [%number% [(block|met(er|re))[s]]] in [the] (direction|horizontal direction|facing|horizontal facing) of %entity/block% [(of|from)]
expressions.description: A helper expression for the direction type.
expressions.examples:
thrust the player upwards
set the block behind the player to water
loop blocks above the player:
    set {_rand} to a random integer between 1 and 10
    set the block {_rand} meters south east of the loop-block to stone
block in horizontal facing of the clicked entity from the player is air
spawn a creeper 1.5 meters horizontally behind the player
spawn a TNT 5 meters above and 2 meters horizontally behind the player
thrust the last spawned TNT in the horizontal direction of the player with speed 0.2
push the player upwards and horizontally forward at speed 0.5
push the clicked entity in in the direction of the player at speed -0.5
open the inventory of the block 2 blocks below the player to the player
teleport the clicked entity behind the player
grow a regular tree 2 meters horizontally behind the player

expressions.name: Distance
expressions.description: The distance between two points.
expressions.examples: if the distance between the player and {home::%uuid of player%} is smaller than 20:\n    message "You're very close to your home!"

expressions.name: Drops
expressions.description: Only works in death events. Holds the drops of the dying creature. Drops can be prevented by removing them with "remove ... from drops", e.g. "remove all pickaxes from the drops", or "clear drops" if you don't want any drops at all.
expressions.examples: clear drops\nremove 4 planks from the drops

expressions.name: Drops Of Block
patterns: [(all|the|all [of] the)] drops of %blocks% [(using|with) %item type% [(as %entity%)]]
expressions.description: A list of the items that will drop when a block is broken.
expressions.examples: on break of block:\n    give drops of block using player's tool to player

expressions.name: Element of
patterns: ([the] first|[the] last|[a] random|[the] %number%(st|nd|rd|th)|[the] %number%(st|nd|rd|th) [to] last) element [out] of %objects%
expressions.description: The first, last or a random element of a set, e.g. a list variable. See also: random
expressions.examples: give a random element out of {free items::*} to the player

expressions.name: Enchant Item
expressions.description:
The enchant item in an enchant prepare event or enchant event.
It can be modified, but enchantments will still be applied in the enchant event.
expressions.examples:
on enchant:
    set the enchanted item to a diamond chestplate
on enchant prepare:
    set the enchant item to a wooden sword

expressions.name: Enchanting Experience Cost
expressions.description:
The cost of enchanting in an enchant event.
This is number that was displayed in the enchantment table, not the actual number of levels removed.
expressions.examples: on enchant:\n    send "Cost: %the displayed enchanting cost%" to player

expressions.name: Enchantment Bonus
expressions.description: The enchantment bonus in an enchant prepare event. This represents the number of bookshelves affecting/surrounding the enchantment table.
expressions.examples: on enchant:\n    send "There are %enchantment bonus% bookshelves surrounding this enchantment table!" to player

expressions.name: Enchantment Level
expressions.description: The level of a particular enchantment on an item.
expressions.examples: player's tool is a sword of sharpness:\n    message "You have a sword of sharpness %level of sharpness of the player's tool% equipped"

expressions.name: Enchantment Offer
expressions.description: The enchantment offer in enchant prepare events.
expressions.examples: on enchant prepare:\n    send "Your enchantment offers are: %the enchantment offers%" to player

expressions.name: Enchantment Offer Cost
expressions.description:
The cost of an enchantment offer. This is displayed to the right of an enchantment offer.
If the cost is changed, it will always be at least 1.
This changes how many levels are required to enchant, but does not change the number of levels removed.
To change the number of levels removed, use the enchant event.
expressions.examples: set cost of enchantment offer 1 to 50

expressions.name: Ender Chest
expressions.description: The ender chest of a player.
expressions.examples: open the player's ender chest to the player

expressions.name: Entities
patterns: [(all [[of] the]|the)] entities of type[s] %entity types% [(in|of) ([world[s]] %worlds%|%chunks%)]
[(all [[of] the]|the)] entities of type[s] %entity types% in radius %number% (of|around) %location%
expressions.description: All entities in all worlds, in a specific world, in a chunk or in a radius around a certain location, e.g. all players, all creepers in the player's world, or players in radius 100 of the player.
expressions.examples:
kill all creepers in the player's world
send "Psst!" to all players within 100 meters of the player
give a diamond to all ops
heal all tamed wolves in radius 2000 around {town center}
delete all monsters in chunk at player

expressions.name: Entity AI
expressions.description: Returns whether an entity has AI.
expressions.examples: set artificial intelligence of target entity to false

expressions.name: Entity Attribute
expressions.description:
The numerical value of an entity's particular attribute.
Note that the movement speed attribute cannot be reliably used for players. For that purpose, use the speed expression instead.
Resetting an entity's attribute is only available in Minecraft 1.11 and above.
expressions.examples: on damage of player:\n    send "You are wounded!"\n    set victim's attack speed attribute to 2

expressions.name: Entity Fire Burn Duration
expressions.description: How much time an entity will be burning for.
expressions.examples: send "You will stop burning in %fire time of player%"

expressions.name: Entity Owner
expressions.description: The owner of a tameable entity, such as a horse or wolf.
expressions.examples: set owner of target entity to player\ndelete owner of target entity\nset {_t} to uuid of tamer of target entity

expressions.name: Exhaustion
expressions.description: The exhaustion of a player. This is mainly used to determine the rate of hunger depletion.
expressions.examples: set exhaustion of all players to 1

expressions.name: Experience
expressions.description: How much experience was spawned in an experience spawn or block break event. Can be changed.
expressions.examples:
on experience spawn:
    add 5 to the spawned experience
on break of coal ore:
    clear dropped experience
on break of diamond ore:
    if tool of player = diamond pickaxe:
        add 100 to dropped experience

expressions.name: Exploded Blocks
expressions.description: Get all the blocks that were destroyed in an explode event
expressions.examples: on explode:\n    loop exploded blocks:\n        add loop-block to {exploded::blocks::*}

expressions.name: Explosion Block Yield
expressions.description:
The percentage of exploded blocks dropped in an explosion event.
When changing the yield, a value greater than 1 will function the same as using 1.
Attempting to change the yield to a value less than 0 will have no effect.
expressions.examples: on explode:\nset the explosion's block yield to 10%

expressions.name: Explosion Yield
expressions.description: The yield of the explosion in an explosion prime event. This is how big the explosion is. When changing the yield, values less than 0 will be ignored. Read this wiki page for more information
expressions.examples: on explosion prime:\n    set the yield of the explosion to 10

expressions.name: Explosive Yield
expressions.description: The yield of an explosive (creeper, primed tnt, fireball, etc.). This is how big of an explosion is caused by the entity. Read this wiki page for more information
expressions.examples: on spawn of a creeper:\n    set the explosive yield of the event-entity to 10

expressions.name: Facing
expressions.description: The facing of an entity or block, i.e. exactly north, south, east, west, up or down (unlike direction which is the exact direction, e.g. '0.5 south and 0.7 east')
expressions.examples: # makes a bridge\nloop blocks from the block below the player in the horizontal facing of the player:\n    set loop-block to cobblestone

expressions.name: Fall Distance
expressions.description: The distance an entity has fallen for.
expressions.examples: set all entities' fall distance to 10\non damage:\n    send "%victim's fall distance%" to victim

expressions.name: Fertilized Blocks
expressions.description: The blocks fertilized in block fertilize events.
expressions.examples: the fertilized blocks

expressions.name: Filter
expressions.description: Filters a list based on a condition. For example, if you ran 'broadcast "something" and "something else" where [string input is "something"]', only "something" would be broadcast as it is the only string that matched the condition.
expressions.examples: send "congrats on being staff!" to all players where [player input has permission "staff"]

expressions.name: Filter Input
expressions.description: Represents the input in a filter expression. For example, if you ran 'broadcast "something" and "something else" where [input is "something"]the condition would be checked twice, using "something" and "something else" as the inputs.
expressions.examples: send "congrats on being staff!" to all players where [input has permission "staff"]

expressions.name: Final Damage
expressions.description: How much damage is done in a damage event, considering all types of damage reduction. Can NOT be changed.
expressions.examples: send "%final damage%" to victim

expressions.name: Firework Effect
patterns: [(flickering|trailing|flickering trailing|trailing flickering)] %firework type% [firework [effect]] colo[u]red %colors% fad(e|ing) [to] %colors%
expressions.description: Represents a 'firework effect' which can be used in the launch firework effect.
expressions.examples: launch flickering trailing burst firework colored blue and green at player\nlaunch trailing flickering star colored purple, yellow, blue, green and red fading to pink at target entity\nlaunch ball large colored red, purple and white fading to light green and black at player's location with duration 1

expressions.name: Flight Mode
expressions.description: Whether the player(s) are allowed to fly. Use Make Fly effect to force player(s) to fly.
expressions.examples: set flight mode of player to true\nsend "%flying state of all players%"

expressions.name: Food Level
expressions.description: The food level of a player from 0 to 10. Has several aliases: food/hunger level/meter/bar.
expressions.examples: set the player's food level to 10

expressions.name: Formatted Date
expressions.description: Converts date to human-readable text format. By default, 'yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss z' (e.g. '2018-03-30 16:03:12 +01') will be used. For reference, see this Wikipedia article.
expressions.examples:
command /date:
    trigger:
        send "Full date: %now formatted human-readable%" to sender
        send "Short date: %now formatted as "yyyy-MM-dd"%" to sender

expressions.name: Former/Future State
expressions.description: Represents the value of an expression before an event happened or the value it will have directly after the event, e.g. the old or new level respectively in a level change event. Note: The past, future and present states of an expression are sometimes called 'time states' of an expression. Note 2: If you don't specify whether to use the past or future state of an expression that has different values, its default value will be used which is usually the value after the event.
expressions.examples:
on teleport:
    former world was "world_nether" # or 'world was'
    world will be "world" # or 'world after the event is'
on tool change:
    past tool is an axe
    the tool after the event will be air
on weather change:
    set {weather::%world%::old} to past weather
    set {weather::%world%::current} to the new weather

expressions.name: Freeze Time
expressions.description: How much time an entity has been in powdered snow for.
expressions.examples: player's freeze time is less than 3 seconds:\n    send "you're about to freeze!" to the player

expressions.name: Furnace Slot
expressions.description: A slot of a furnace, i.e. either the ore, fuel or result slot. Remember to use 'block' and not 'furnace', as 'furnace' is not an existing expression.
expressions.examples:
set the fuel slot of the clicked block to a lava bucket
set the block's ore slot to 64 iron ore
give the result of the block to the player
clear the result slot of the block

expressions.name: Game Mode
expressions.description: The gamemode of a player. (Gamemodes)
expressions.examples: player's gamemode is survival\nset the player's gamemode to creative

expressions.name: Gamerule Value
expressions.description: The gamerule value of a world.
expressions.examples: set the gamerule commandBlockOutput of world "world" to false

expressions.name: Gliding State
expressions.description: Sets of gets gliding state of player. It allows you to set gliding state of entity even if they do not have an Elytra equipped.
expressions.examples: set gliding of player to off

expressions.name: Glowing
expressions.description: Indicates if targeted entity is glowing (new 1.9 effect) or not. Glowing entities can be seen through walls.
expressions.examples: set glowing of player to true

expressions.name: Gravity
expressions.description: If entity is affected by gravity or not, i.e. if it has Minecraft 1.10+ NoGravity flag.
expressions.examples: set gravity of player off

expressions.name: Group
expressions.description:
The primary group or all groups of a player. This expression requires Vault and a compatible permissions plugin to be installed.
If you have LuckPerms, ensure you have vault integration enabled in the luck perms configurations.
expressions.examples: on join:\n    broadcast "%group of player%" # this is the player's primary group\n    broadcast "%groups of player%" # this is all of the player's groups

expressions.name: Hanging Entity/Remover
expressions.description: Returns the hanging entity or remover in hanging break and place events.

expressions.name: Hash
expressions.description:
Hashes the given text using the MD5 or SHA-256 algorithms. Each algorithm is suitable for different use cases.

MD5 is provided mostly for backwards compatibility, as it is outdated and not secure. SHA-256 is more secure, and can used to hash somewhat confidental data like IP addresses and even passwords. It is not that secure out of the box, so please consider using salt when dealing with passwords! When hashing data, you must specify algorithms that will be used for security reasons!

Please note that a hash cannot be reversed under normal circumstanses. You will not be able to get original value from a hash with Skript.
expressions.examples:
command /setpass &lt;text&gt;:
    trigger:
        set {password::%uuid of player%} to text-argument hashed with SHA-256
command /login &lt;text&gt;:
    trigger:
        if text-argument hashed with SHA-256 is {password::%uuid of player%}:
            message "Login successful."
        else:
            message "Wrong password!"

expressions.name: Hatching Entity Type
expressions.description: The type of the entity that will be hatched in a Player Egg Throw event.
expressions.examples: on player egg throw:\n    set the hatching entity type to a primed tnt

expressions.name: Hatching Number
expressions.description:
The number of entities that will be hatched in a Player Egg Throw event.
Please note that no more than 127 entities can be hatched at once.
expressions.examples: on player egg throw:\n    set the hatching number to 10

expressions.name: Head location
expressions.description:
The location of an entity's head, mostly useful for players and e.g. looping blocks in the player's line of sight.
Please note that this location is only accurate for entities whose head is exactly above their center, i.e. players, endermen, zombies, skeletons, etc., but not sheep, pigs or cows.
expressions.examples: set the block at the player's head to air\nset the block in front of the player's eyes to glass\nloop blocks in front of the player's head:

expressions.name: Heal Amount
expressions.description: The amount of health healed in a healing event.
expressions.examples: increase heal amount by 2\nremove 0.5 from heal amount

expressions.name: Heal Reason
expressions.description: The heal reason of a heal event. Please click on the link for more information.
expressions.examples: on heal:\n    if heal reason = satiated:\n        send "You ate enough food and gained health back!" to player

expressions.name: Health
expressions.description: The health of a creature, e.g. a player, mob, villager, etc. The minimum value is 0, and the maximum is the creature's max health (e.g. 10 for players).
expressions.examples: message "You have %health% HP left."

expressions.name: Hidden Players
expressions.description: The players hidden from a player that were hidden using the player visibility effect.
expressions.examples: message "&lt;light red&gt;You are currently hiding: &lt;light gray&gt;%hidden players of the player%"

expressions.name: Highest Solid Block
expressions.description: Returns the highest solid block at the x and z coordinates of the world of a given location.
expressions.examples: highest block at location of arg-player

expressions.name: Hostname
expressions.description: The hostname used by the connecting player to connect to the server in a connect event.
expressions.examples: on connect:\n    hostname is "testers.example.com"\n    send "Welcome back tester!"

expressions.name: Hotbar Button
expressions.description: The hotbar button clicked in an inventory click event.
expressions.examples: on inventory click:\n    send "You clicked the hotbar button %hotbar button%!"

expressions.name: Hotbar Slot
expressions.description: The currently selected hotbar slot. To retrieve its number use Slot Index expression. Use future and past tense to grab the previous slot in an item change event, see example.
expressions.examples:
message "%player's current hotbar slot%"
set player's selected hotbar slot to slot 4 of player

send "index of player's current hotbar slot = 1" # second slot from the left

on item held change:
    if the selected hotbar slot was a diamond:
        set the currently selected hotbar slot to slot 5 of player

expressions.name: Hover List
expressions.description: The list when you hover on the player counts of the server in the server list. This can be changed using texts or players in a server list ping event only. Adding players to the list means adding the name of the players. And note that, for example if there are 5 online players (includes fake online count) in the server and the hover list is set to 3 values, Minecraft will show "... and 2 more ..." at end of the list.
expressions.examples:
on server list ping:
    clear the hover list
    add "&aWelcome to the &6Minecraft &aserver!" to the hover list
    add "" to the hover list # A blank line
    add "&cThere are &6%online players count% &conline players!" to the hover list

expressions.name: Humidity
expressions.description: Humidity of given blocks.
expressions.examples: set {_humidity} to event-block's humidity

expressions.name: IP
expressions.since: 1.4, 2.2-dev26 (when used in connect event), 2.3 (when used in server list ping event)
expressions.description: The IP address of a player, or the connected player in a connect event, or the pinger in a server list ping event.
expressions.examples:
ban the IP address of the player
broadcast "Banned the IP %IP of player%"

on connect:
    log "[%now%] %player% (%ip%) is connected to the server."

on server list ping:
    send "%IP-address%" to the console

expressions.name: Index Of
